Based on the overall analysis of UNICEF as a key partner, it is suggested to enter a new agreement the organization and provide support during the period 2018-2021, which is in line with the new UNICEF Strategic Plan 2018-2021. UNICEF will continue to receive an unearmarked allocation (38 000 000 SEK) for ongoing, revised or new operations in accordance with the objectives of the Humanitarian programmes (UN Appeals and UNICEF Humanitarian Action for Children/HAC). For 2018, an additional amount of 202 000 000 SEK will be made available for specific humanitarian programmes in 15 crises which will be presented below. Furthermore, support will be provided to technical projects and programmes that may be outside the UNICEF HAC Appeals but that contribute to the strengthening and improving activities and cross cutting issues related to humanitarian appeals.
An amount of SEK 3 200 000 for 2018 and SEK 2 300 000 for 2019 will also be utilized for the inter-agency collective service for community engagement and accountability project proposal which is hosted by UNICEF on the behalf of the Communication with Communities Working Group (CwCWG). The funds will be directed for the Central African Republic (CAR) context. This project aims to improve the humanitarian response in CAR by strengthening the accountability to the affected population (AAP).

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 Den globala trenden med ökade humanitära behov fortsätter under 2018 och i början på året beräknas 90,9 miljoner människor i 26 länder vara i behov av humanitärt stöd och FN:s appeller uppgår till 22,5 miljarder dollar.
Sida genomför årligen en humanitär allokeringsprocess då de omkring 15 stora pågående humanitära kriserna analyseras utifrån de humanitära behoven och där de mest relevanta av strategiska partnerorganisationer identifieras. Det aktuella stödet till UNICEF i 15 länder/kriser baseras på Sidas humanitära allokering, som färdigställdes under slutet av 2017. Stödet till UNICEF bedöms relevant för att uppnå målen i Strategi för Sveriges humanitära bistånd genom Sida 2017-2020.
Under 2017 uppgick det totala utbetalda Sida humanitära bidraget till UNICEF till 351 000 000 SEK. Det totala initiala bidrag som föreslås för 2018 uppgår till 243 200 000 SEK och är uppdelat på de följande kategorierna:
A. Landspecifikt stöd: Den förslagna landfördelningen för 2018 (identifierade under allokeringsprocessen) omfattar totalt SEK 202 000 000 med stöd till UNICEFs humanitära arbete inom sektorerna hälsa, nutrition, utbildning, barnskyddsfrågor, könsrelaterat våld och vatten och sanitet:
O-öronmärkt stöd: 1. Syrien krisen 25 000 000 SEK 2. Somaliakrisen 14 000 000 SEK 3. Demokratiska Folk Republiken Korea 8 000 000 SEK 4. Jemen 30 000 000 SEK 5. Niger 6 000 000 SEK 6. Nigeria 25 000 000 SEK 7. Irak 13 000 000 SEK 8. Etiopien 25 000 000 SEK 9. Mali 7 000 000 SEK 10. Tchad 4 000 000 SEK 11. Sudan 10 000 000 SEK 12. Sydsudan 14 000 000 SEK
Öronmärkt stöd: 1. Burundi 6 000 000 SEK (Skydd av barn och WASH) 2. CAR 5 000 000 SEK (Rapid Response Mechanism/RRM) 3. DRK 10 000 000 SEK (Rapid Response to Movements of Population (RRMP)
B. Snabb responsmekanism i form av oallokerade medel: Det föreslås även ett stöd om 38 000 000 SEK för 2018 och 2 000 000 SEK per år för 2019, 2020 och 2021 som UNICEF kan rekvirera och använda efter godkännande från Sida, för nya eller förvärrade humanitära kriser.
C. Slutligen föreslås metod/tematiskt stöd till projekt som bidrar till att stärka den humanitära responsen, specifikt ökad deltagande av den drabbade befolkningen (AAP) i CAR men 3 200 000 SEK för 2018 och 2 300 000 SEK för 2019.
Det föreslås at Sida ska ingå två avtal med UNICEF i syfte att särskilja det stöd som går till de humanitära appellerna respektive metodstöd. Detta är i enlighet med önskemål från UNICEF i syfte att förenkla deras hantering.
Sidas stöd till UNICEF är baserat på FNs samordnade humanitära responsplaner (HRP) samt UNICEFs ’Humanitarian Action for Children' (HAC). Bidraget kommer att allokeras till UNICEF på landnivå med både öronmärkt eller o-öronmärkt stöd. Sida väljer att öronmärkta stödet till vissa kriser för att säkerställa att de sektorer eller komponenter med störst humanitära behoven enligt behovsanalysen adresseras. Inom det humanitära systemet är UNICEF en central aktör med ett särskilt mandat som riktar sig till barn och mödrar i konfliktsituationer eller naturkatastrofer. Genom stödet kommer organisationen därmed ge livräddande och livsuppehållande stöd till de mest utsatta grupperna med fokus på barn och kvinnor i humanitära situationer. Stödet kommer att inkludera nya akuta humanitära situationer, pågående samt eskalerande kriser.
Sidas stöd till UNICEF kommer förutom att bidra med humanitär finansiering för att bistå utsatta grupper i humanitära kriser även att bidra till samordnad och effektiv respons i de utvalda länderna. UNICEF ansvarar för att leda och samordna de globala klustren för nutrition, utbildning, vatten och sanitet samt har ansvar för skydd av barn.
UNICEF har framfört att tidig utbetalning av årliga bidrag för humanitära insatser är en förutsättning för att organisationen ska kunna ingå förpliktelser i form av anställning av personal och kunna påbörja den upphandling av de varor och tjänster som behövs för den humanitära responsen. UNICEF har en väl utvecklad logistik med lager i regionala depåer och har en roll i det humanitära systemet att även förse andra implementerande partners med varor. Humanitära kriser är till sin karaktär snabbt skiftande både geografiskt och i intensitet, UNICEF måste därför vara beredda att kunna flytta såväl personal som förnödenheter.
Sida delar UNICEFs bedömning att det föreligger ett behov av att kunna planera och förbereda insatser utan onödig fördröjning och bedömer därför att samtliga medel för projektet ska utbetalas ut omgående för att möjliggöra planering och uppstart av projektet till 1 januari 2018. Ett avsteg från Sidas vanliga rutiner om uppdelade betalningar bedöms motiverat.
Bedömningspromemorian har skrivits på engelska med anledning av att engelskspråkig personal i fält är delaktig i beredning och uppföljning av insatsen, i enlighet med Generaldirektörens beslut om Sidas språkvalsmatris med tillämpningsanvisningar från den 1 mars 2013.

To save lives and alleviate suffering for children in who's lives have been affected due to conflict and natural disasters worldwide; mainly in the sectors of nutrition, health, water and sanitation and hygiene, as well as in emergency education, child protection and gender-based violence (GBV).

sector.narrative: Basic Health Care Services in Emergencies

tag.narrative: 17.17 - Encourage and promote effective public, public-private and civil society partnerships, building on the experience and resourcing strategies of partnerships

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: Sida has received the annual report for 2019 (30 June 2020) and we are happy to note that in the more than 20 different contexts the following examples of achievements are reported: In Cameroon UNICEF humanitarian assistance primarily focused on refugees who fled the armed conflict in Central African Republic (CAR) and their host communities, to IDPs caused by the ongoing crisis in the North West and South West of Cameroon and to persons displaced by Boko Haram attacks in Far North region inlcuding refugees and outsed restablished camps. - Nationally, 79 311 (target 65 064) children aged 6-59 months with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) were admitted for treatment where 137 additional primary health facilities were possible to include in this emergency response (compared to a target figure of 702). - Nationally, UNICEF implementing partners reached 54 240 target families/households with at least 1 long-lasting insecticidal nets or 83% of the target figure of 62 739 familieis/households. - 152 947 children (6 months to 15 years) were vaccinated against measles (target 266 492). - Funding shortfalls impacted the planned WASH results with only 22 000 people supported with sustainable access to safe drinking water against a taret of 110 000 while 23 456 people were assisted with access to adequate basic sanitation agianst a target of 75 000 pople. The WASH sector received an overall funding level of only 8% against the requirement. - Also in the education sector, low funding led to poor emergency education results in 2019. Over 5 900 girls and boys (3-17 years) receive learning materials, well below the target of 217 989. - With a bit more appropriate funding for child protection, 141 555 children were reached with psycho-social support including child friendly spaces, against a goal of 289 789. In Syria, despite the complex environment UNICEF worked to deliver humanitarian assistance within the Whole of Syria (WoS) approach. UNICEF focused on multi-sectoral response addressing Health, Nutrition, WASH, Education and Protection needs and Social Protection. UNICEF has been progressively strengthening its focus on the longer term by scaling-up resilience building interventions and will continue to move in this direction: - UNICEF supported over 2 million women and children to receive primary health care consultations across Syria. This was 91% of target and was due to the constrained access in some areas of Idlib. - The expansion of vaccination services ensured that over 500 000 children under-1 received diphteria-tetanus-pertussis vaccination and over 3 million children were immunized against polio. - Access to services by vulnerable groups such as women and children were enhanced by the increasing use of mobile teams with female health workers in some of the hard to reach communities and IDP camps. - UNICEF supported the screening of about 1.8 million children under-5 and pregnant and lactating women for acute malnutrition. Of the total children screened, 11 498 were found to be affected by SAM and received life-saving treatment. - Emergency WASH interventions reached over 1 million people through the distribution of non-food items (NFIs) including family hygiene kits, soap and aqua tabs and installation of water tanks in camps, host communities and IDP shelters across the country. - To strengthen girls' and boys' coping mechanisms and resilience, UNICEF provided psychosocial support services to about 393 500 children (50% girls) through fixed and mobile modalities. The target was overachieved as services were provided to address needs arising from new displacements and expansion in Deir-ez-Zor, Al Hasakeh and Aleppo. In Nigeria, UNICEF delivered an integrated package of interventions to conflict-affected populations in the northeast and handed over a greater share of service delivery to partners whose capacity in the region is increasing: - UNICEF reached 249 776 people in Borno state with temporary access to safe water, primarily through water trucking in hard-to-reach areas and areas where geological issues do not allow for the construction of new water facilities. - In collaboration with the Borno and Adamawa states, UNICEF sustained access to safe water to 771 428 people in Borno and 1.7 million people in Adamawa. - UNICEF supported the release of 461 children (57 girls and 404 boys) in line with the action plan signed with relevant partners. UNICEF is also providing reintegration services to all released children. - 358 962 children received psychosocial support services (reached 100% of target) and worked to reunify 275 unaccompanied and separated children with their familieis, while 752 children benefitted from alternative care placement. - Birth registration results exceeded planned targets, for children under-5 there were 94% births registered (versus a target of 54%), while children under-1 were registered 99% (target 72%). - A number of 3 969 664 conflict-affected people were reached with integrated primary health care services (approximately half of which were under-5). This included curative care, preventive services and women supported with safe deliveries and post-natal care. - A number of 138 772 children (target 158 488) aged 6-59 months with SAM were admitted to therapeutic care for specified period where 95% recovered.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

New/additional funds to address COVID-19 Each year Sida undertakes a humanitarian allocation process (Humanitarian Crises Analysis/HCA) in which all humanitarian crises are analysed, and where the partners most relevant to respond to the identified needs are selected. Based on the overall analysis of UNICEF as a key partner, it is suggested to enter a new agreement the organization and provide support during the period 2018-2021, which is in line with the new UNICEF Strategic Plan 2018-2021. UNICEF will continue to receive an unearmarked allocation (38 000 000 SEK) for ongoing, revised or new operations in accordance with the objectives of the Humanitarian programmes (UN Appeals and UNICEF Humanitarian Action for Children/HAC). For 2018, an additional amount of 202 000 000 SEK will be made available for specific humanitarian programmes in 15 crises which will be presented below. Furthermore, support will be provided to technical projects and programmes that may be outside the UNICEF HAC Appeals but that contribute to the strengthening and improving activities and cross cutting issues related to humanitarian appeals.
An amount of SEK 3 200 000 for 2018 and SEK 2 300 000 for 2019 will also be utilized for the inter-agency collective service for community engagement and accountability project proposal which is hosted by UNICEF on the behalf of the Communication with Communities Working Group (CwCWG). The funds will be directed for the Central African Republic (CAR) context. This project aims to improve the humanitarian response in CAR by strengthening the accountability to the affected population (AAP).

Bidraget kommer att allokeras till UNICEF på landnivå med både öronmärkt eller o-öronmärkt stöd. Sida väljer att öronmärkta stödet till vissa kriser för att säkerställa att de sektorer eller komponenter med störst humanitära behoven enligt behovsanalysen adresseras. Inom det humanitära systemet är UNICEF en central aktör med ett särskilt mandat som riktar sig till barn och mödrar i konfliktsituationer eller naturkatastrofer. Genom stödet kommer organisationen därmed ge livräddande och livsuppehållande stöd till de mest utsatta grupperna med fokus på barn och kvinnor i humanitära situationer. Stödet kommer att inkludera nya akuta humanitära situationer, pågående samt eskalerande kriser.
Sidas stöd till UNICEF kommer förutom att bidra med humanitär finansiering för att bistå utsatta grupper i humanitära kriser även att bidra till samordnad och effektiv respons i de utvalda länderna. UNICEF ansvarar för att leda och samordna de globala klustren för nutrition, utbildning, vatten och sanitet samt har ansvar för skydd av barn.
UNICEF har framfört att tidig utbetalning av årliga bidrag för humanitära insatser är en förutsättning för att organisationen ska kunna ingå förpliktelser i form av anställning av personal och kunna påbörja den upphandling av de varor och tjänster som behövs för den humanitära responsen. UNICEF har en väl utvecklad logistik med lager i regionala depåer och har en roll i det humanitära systemet att även förse andra implementerande partners med varor. Humanitära kriser är till sin karaktär snabbt skiftande både geografiskt och i intensitet, UNICEF måste därför vara beredda att kunna flytta såväl personal som förnödenheter.
Sida delar UNICEFs bedömning att det föreligger ett behov av att kunna planera och förbereda insatser utan onödig fördröjning och bedömer därför att samtliga medel för projektet ska utbetalas ut omgående för att möjliggöra planering och uppstart av projektet till 1 januari 2018. Ett avsteg från Sidas vanliga rutiner om uppdelade betalningar bedöms motiverat.
Bedömningspromemorian har skrivits på engelska med anledning av att engelskspråkig personal i fält är delaktig i beredning och uppföljning av insatsen, i enlighet med Generaldirektörens beslut om Sidas språkvalsmatris med tillämpningsanvisningar från den 1 mars 2013.

To save lives and alleviate suffering for children in who's lives have been affected due to conflict and natural disasters worldwide; mainly in the sectors of nutrition, health, water and sanitation and hygiene, as well as in emergency education, child protection and gender-based violence (GBV).

tag.narrative: 17.17 - Encourage and promote effective public, public-private and civil society partnerships, building on the experience and resourcing strategies of partnerships
17.17 - Encourage and promote effective public, public-private and civil society partnerships, building on the experience and resourcing strategies of partnerships.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: Sida has received the annual report for 2019 (30 June 2020) and we are happy to note that in the more than 20 different contexts the following examples of achievements are reported: In Cameroon UNICEF humanitarian assistance primarily focused on refugees who fled the armed conflict in Central African Republic (CAR) and their host communities, to IDPs caused by the ongoing crisis in the North West and South West of Cameroon and to persons displaced by Boko Haram attacks in Far North region inlcuding refugees and outsed restablished camps. - Nationally, 79 311 (target 65 064) children aged 6-59 months with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) were admitted for treatment where 137 additional primary health facilities were possible to include in this emergency response (compared to a target figure of 702). - Nationally, UNICEF implementing partners reached 54 240 target families/households with at least 1 long-lasting insecticidal nets or 83% of the target figure of 62 739 familieis/households. - 152 947 children (6 months to 15 years) were vaccinated against measles (target 266 492). - Funding shortfalls impacted the planned WASH results with only 22 000 people supported with sustainable access to safe drinking water against a taret of 110 000 while 23 456 people were assisted with access to adequate basic sanitation agianst a target of 75 000 pople. The WASH sector received an overall funding level of only 8% against the requirement. - Also in the education sector, low funding led to poor emergency education results in 2019. Over 5 900 girls and boys (3-17 years) receive learning materials, well below the target of 217 989. - With a bit more appropriate funding for child protection, 141 555 children were reached with psycho-social support including child friendly spaces, against a goal of 289 789. In Syria, despite the complex environment UNICEF worked to deliver humanitarian assistance within the Whole of Syria (WoS) approach. UNICEF focused on multi-sectoral response addressing Health, Nutrition, WASH, Education and Protection needs and Social Protection. UNICEF has been progressively strengthening its focus on the longer term by scaling-up resilience building interventions and will continue to move in this direction: - UNICEF supported over 2 million women and children to receive primary health care consultations across Syria. This was 91% of target and was due to the constrained access in some areas of Idlib. - The expansion of vaccination services ensured that over 500 000 children under-1 received diphteria-tetanus-pertussis vaccination and over 3 million children were immunized against polio. - Access to services by vulnerable groups such as women and children were enhanced by the increasing use of mobile teams with female health workers in some of the hard to reach communities and IDP camps. - UNICEF supported the screening of about 1.8 million children under-5 and pregnant and lactating women for acute malnutrition. Of the total children screened, 11 498 were found to be affected by SAM and received life-saving treatment. - Emergency WASH interventions reached over 1 million people through the distribution of non-food items (NFIs) including family hygiene kits, soap and aqua tabs and installation of water tanks in camps, host communities and IDP shelters across the country. - To strengthen girls' and boys' coping mechanisms and resilience, UNICEF provided psychosocial support services to about 393 500 children (50% girls) through fixed and mobile modalities. The target was overachieved as services were provided to address needs arising from new displacements and expansion in Deir-ez-Zor, Al Hasakeh and Aleppo. In Nigeria, UNICEF delivered an integrated package of interventions to conflict-affected populations in the northeast and handed over a greater share of service delivery to partners whose capacity in the region is increasing: - UNICEF reached 249 776 people in Borno state with temporary access to safe water, primarily through water trucking in hard-to-reach areas and areas where geological issues do not allow for the construction of new water facilities. - In collaboration with the Borno and Adamawa states, UNICEF sustained access to safe water to 771 428 people in Borno and 1.7 million people in Adamawa. - UNICEF supported the release of 461 children (57 girls and 404 boys) in line with the action plan signed with relevant partners. UNICEF is also providing reintegration services to all released children. - 358 962 children received psychosocial support services (reached 100% of target) and worked to reunify 275 unaccompanied and separated children with their familieis, while 752 children benefitted from alternative care placement. - Birth registration results exceeded planned targets, for children under-5 there were 94% births registered (versus a target of 54%), while children under-1 were registered 99% (target 72%). - A number of 3 969 664 conflict-affected people were reached with integrated primary health care services (approximately half of which were under-5). This included curative care, preventive services and women supported with safe deliveries and post-natal care. - A number of 138 772 children (target 158 488) aged 6-59 months with SAM were admitted to therapeutic care for specified period where 95% recovered.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

New/additional funds to address COVID-19 Each year Sida undertakes a humanitarian allocation process (Humanitarian Crises Analysis/HCA) in which all humanitarian crises are analysed, and where the partners most relevant to respond to the identified needs are selected. Based on the overall analysis of UNICEF as a key partner, it is suggested to enter a new agreement the organization and provide support during the period 2018-2021, which is in line with the new UNICEF Strategic Plan 2018-2021. UNICEF will continue to receive an unearmarked allocation (38 000 000 SEK) for ongoing, revised or new operations in accordance with the objectives of the Humanitarian programmes (UN Appeals and UNICEF Humanitarian Action for Children/HAC). For 2018, an additional amount of 202 000 000 SEK will be made available for specific humanitarian programmes in 15 crises which will be presented below. Furthermore, support will be provided to technical projects and programmes that may be outside the UNICEF HAC Appeals but that contribute to the strengthening and improving activities and cross cutting issues related to humanitarian appeals.
An amount of SEK 3 200 000 for 2018 and SEK 2 300 000 for 2019 will also be utilized for the inter-agency collective service for community engagement and accountability project proposal which is hosted by UNICEF on the behalf of the Communication with Communities Working Group (CwCWG). The funds will be directed for the Central African Republic (CAR) context. This project aims to improve the humanitarian response in CAR by strengthening the accountability to the affected population (AAP).

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 Den globala trenden med ökade humanitära behov fortsätter under 2018 och i början på året beräknas 90,9 miljoner människor i 26 länder vara i behov av humanitärt stöd och FN:s appeller uppgår till 22,5 miljarder dollar.
Sida genomför årligen en humanitär allokeringsprocess då de omkring 15 stora pågående humanitära kriserna analyseras utifrån de humanitära behoven och där de mest relevanta av strategiska partnerorganisationer identifieras. Det aktuella stödet till UNICEF i 15 länder/kriser baseras på Sidas humanitära allokering, som färdigställdes under slutet av 2017. Stödet till UNICEF bedöms relevant för att uppnå målen i Strategi för Sveriges humanitära bistånd genom Sida 2017-2020.
Under 2017 uppgick det totala utbetalda Sida humanitära bidraget till UNICEF till 351 000 000 SEK. Det totala initiala bidrag som föreslås för 2018 uppgår till 243 200 000 SEK och är uppdelat på de följande kategorierna:
A. Landspecifikt stöd: Den förslagna landfördelningen för 2018 (identifierade under allokeringsprocessen) omfattar totalt SEK 202 000 000 med stöd till UNICEFs humanitära arbete inom sektorerna hälsa, nutrition, utbildning, barnskyddsfrågor, könsrelaterat våld och vatten och sanitet:
O-öronmärkt stöd: 1. Syrien krisen 25 000 000 SEK 2. Somaliakrisen 14 000 000 SEK 3. Demokratiska Folk Republiken Korea 8 000 000 SEK 4. Jemen 30 000 000 SEK 5. Niger 6 000 000 SEK 6. Nigeria 25 000 000 SEK 7. Irak 13 000 000 SEK 8. Etiopien 25 000 000 SEK 9. Mali 7 000 000 SEK 10. Tchad 4 000 000 SEK 11. Sudan 10 000 000 SEK 12. Sydsudan 14 000 000 SEK
Öronmärkt stöd: 1. Burundi 6 000 000 SEK (Skydd av barn och WASH) 2. CAR 5 000 000 SEK (Rapid Response Mechanism/RRM) 3. DRK 10 000 000 SEK (Rapid Response to Movements of Population (RRMP)
B. Snabb responsmekanism i form av oallokerade medel: Det föreslås även ett stöd om 38 000 000 SEK för 2018 och 2 000 000 SEK per år för 2019, 2020 och 2021 som UNICEF kan rekvirera och använda efter godkännande från Sida, för nya eller förvärrade humanitära kriser.
C. Slutligen föreslås metod/tematiskt stöd till projekt som bidrar till att stärka den humanitära responsen, specifikt ökad deltagande av den drabbade befolkningen (AAP) i CAR men 3 200 000 SEK för 2018 och 2 300 000 SEK för 2019.
Det föreslås at Sida ska ingå två avtal med UNICEF i syfte att särskilja det stöd som går till de humanitära appellerna respektive metodstöd. Detta är i enlighet med önskemål från UNICEF i syfte att förenkla deras hantering.
Sidas stöd till UNICEF är baserat på FNs samordnade humanitära responsplaner (HRP) samt UNICEFs ’Humanitarian Action for Children' (HAC). Bidraget kommer att allokeras till UNICEF på landnivå med både öronmärkt eller o-öronmärkt stöd. Sida väljer att öronmärkta stödet till vissa kriser för att säkerställa att de sektorer eller komponenter med störst humanitära behoven enligt behovsanalysen adresseras. Inom det humanitära systemet är UNICEF en central aktör med ett särskilt mandat som riktar sig till barn och mödrar i konfliktsituationer eller naturkatastrofer. Genom stödet kommer organisationen därmed ge livräddande och livsuppehållande stöd till de mest utsatta grupperna med fokus på barn och kvinnor i humanitära situationer. Stödet kommer att inkludera nya akuta humanitära situationer, pågående samt eskalerande kriser.
Sidas stöd till UNICEF kommer förutom att bidra med humanitär finansiering för att bistå utsatta grupper i humanitära kriser även att bidra till samordnad och effektiv respons i de utvalda länderna. UNICEF ansvarar för att leda och samordna de globala klustren för nutrition, utbildning, vatten och sanitet samt har ansvar för skydd av barn.
UNICEF har framfört att tidig utbetalning av årliga bidrag för humanitära insatser är en förutsättning för att organisationen ska kunna ingå förpliktelser i form av anställning av personal och kunna påbörja den upphandling av de varor och tjänster som behövs för den humanitära responsen. UNICEF har en väl utvecklad logistik med lager i regionala depåer och har en roll i det humanitära systemet att även förse andra implementerande partners med varor. Humanitära kriser är till sin karaktär snabbt skiftande både geografiskt och i intensitet, UNICEF måste därför vara beredda att kunna flytta såväl personal som förnödenheter.
Sida delar UNICEFs bedömning att det föreligger ett behov av att kunna planera och förbereda insatser utan onödig fördröjning och bedömer därför att samtliga medel för projektet ska utbetalas ut omgående för att möjliggöra planering och uppstart av projektet till 1 januari 2018. Ett avsteg från Sidas vanliga rutiner om uppdelade betalningar bedöms motiverat.
Bedömningspromemorian har skrivits på engelska med anledning av att engelskspråkig personal i fält är delaktig i beredning och uppföljning av insatsen, i enlighet med Generaldirektörens beslut om Sidas språkvalsmatris med tillämpningsanvisningar från den 1 mars 2013.

To save lives and alleviate suffering for children in who's lives have been affected due to conflict and natural disasters worldwide; mainly in the sectors of nutrition, health, water and sanitation and hygiene, as well as in emergency education, child protection and gender-based violence (GBV).

Over 5 900 girls and boys (3-17 years) receive learning materials, well below the target of 217 989. - With a bit more appropriate funding for child protection, 141 555 children were reached with psycho-social support including child friendly spaces, against a goal of 289 789. In Syria, despite the complex environment UNICEF worked to deliver humanitarian assistance within the Whole of Syria (WoS) approach. UNICEF focused on multi-sectoral response addressing Health, Nutrition, WASH, Education and Protection needs and Social Protection. UNICEF has been progressively strengthening its focus on the longer term by scaling-up resilience building interventions and will continue to move in this direction: - UNICEF supported over 2 million women and children to receive primary health care consultations across Syria. This was 91% of target and was due to the constrained access in some areas of Idlib. - The expansion of vaccination services ensured that over 500 000 children under-1 received diphteria-tetanus-pertussis vaccination and over 3 million children were immunized against polio. - Access to services by vulnerable groups such as women and children were enhanced by the increasing use of mobile teams with female health workers in some of the hard to reach communities and IDP camps. - UNICEF supported the screening of about 1.8 million children under-5 and pregnant and lactating women for acute malnutrition. Of the total children screened, 11 498 were found to be affected by SAM and received life-saving treatment. - Emergency WASH interventions reached over 1 million people through the distribution of non-food items (NFIs) including family hygiene kits, soap and aqua tabs and installation of water tanks in camps, host communities and IDP shelters across the country. - To strengthen girls' and boys' coping mechanisms and resilience, UNICEF provided psychosocial support services to about 393 500 children (50% girls) through fixed and mobile modalities. The target was overachieved as services were provided to address needs arising from new displacements and expansion in Deir-ez-Zor, Al Hasakeh and Aleppo. In Nigeria, UNICEF delivered an integrated package of interventions to conflict-affected populations in the northeast and handed over a greater share of service delivery to partners whose capacity in the region is increasing: - UNICEF reached 249 776 people in Borno state with temporary access to safe water, primarily through water trucking in hard-to-reach areas and areas where geological issues do not allow for the construction of new water facilities. - In collaboration with the Borno and Adamawa states, UNICEF sustained access to safe water to 771 428 people in Borno and 1.7 million people in Adamawa. - UNICEF supported the release of 461 children (57 girls and 404 boys) in line with the action plan signed with relevant partners. UNICEF is also providing reintegration services to all released children. - 358 962 children received psychosocial support services (reached 100% of target) and worked to reunify 275 unaccompanied and separated children with their familieis, while 752 children benefitted from alternative care placement. - Birth registration results exceeded planned targets, for children under-5 there were 94% births registered (versus a target of 54%), while children under-1 were registered 99% (target 72%). - A number of 3 969 664 conflict-affected people were reached with integrated primary health care services (approximately half of which were under-5). This included curative care, preventive services and women supported with safe deliveries and post-natal care. - A number of 138 772 children (target 158 488) aged 6-59 months with SAM were admitted to therapeutic care for specified period where 95% recovered.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

New/additional funds to address COVID-19 Each year Sida undertakes a humanitarian allocation process (Humanitarian Crises Analysis/HCA) in which all humanitarian crises are analysed, and where the partners most relevant to respond to the identified needs are selected. Based on the overall analysis of UNICEF as a key partner, it is suggested to enter a new agreement the organization and provide support during the period 2018-2021, which is in line with the new UNICEF Strategic Plan 2018-2021. UNICEF will continue to receive an unearmarked allocation (38 000 000 SEK) for ongoing, revised or new operations in accordance with the objectives of the Humanitarian programmes (UN Appeals and UNICEF Humanitarian Action for Children/HAC). For 2018, an additional amount of 202 000 000 SEK will be made available for specific humanitarian programmes in 15 crises which will be presented below. Furthermore, support will be provided to technical projects and programmes that may be outside the UNICEF HAC Appeals but that contribute to the strengthening and improving activities and cross cutting issues related to humanitarian appeals.
An amount of SEK 3 200 000 for 2018 and SEK 2 300 000 for 2019 will also be utilized for the inter-agency collective service for community engagement and accountability project proposal which is hosted by UNICEF on the behalf of the Communication with Communities Working Group (CwCWG). The funds will be directed for the Central African Republic (CAR) context. This project aims to improve the humanitarian response in CAR by strengthening the accountability to the affected population (AAP).

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 Den globala trenden med ökade humanitära behov fortsätter under 2018 och i början på året beräknas 90,9 miljoner människor i 26 länder vara i behov av humanitärt stöd och FN:s appeller uppgår till 22,5 miljarder dollar.
Sida genomför årligen en humanitär allokeringsprocess då de omkring 15 stora pågående humanitära kriserna analyseras utifrån de humanitära behoven och där de mest relevanta av strategiska partnerorganisationer identifieras. Det aktuella stödet till UNICEF i 15 länder/kriser baseras på Sidas humanitära allokering, som färdigställdes under slutet av 2017. Stödet till UNICEF bedöms relevant för att uppnå målen i Strategi för Sveriges humanitära bistånd genom Sida 2017-2020.
Under 2017 uppgick det totala utbetalda Sida humanitära bidraget till UNICEF till 351 000 000 SEK. Det totala initiala bidrag som föreslås för 2018 uppgår till 243 200 000 SEK och är uppdelat på de följande kategorierna:
A. Landspecifikt stöd: Den förslagna landfördelningen för 2018 (identifierade under allokeringsprocessen) omfattar totalt SEK 202 000 000 med stöd till UNICEFs humanitära arbete inom sektorerna hälsa, nutrition, utbildning, barnskyddsfrågor, könsrelaterat våld och vatten och sanitet:
O-öronmärkt stöd: 1. Syrien krisen 25 000 000 SEK 2. Somaliakrisen 14 000 000 SEK 3. Demokratiska Folk Republiken Korea 8 000 000 SEK 4. Jemen 30 000 000 SEK 5. Niger 6 000 000 SEK 6. Nigeria 25 000 000 SEK 7. Irak 13 000 000 SEK 8. Etiopien 25 000 000 SEK 9. Mali 7 000 000 SEK 10. Tchad 4 000 000 SEK 11. Sudan 10 000 000 SEK 12. Sydsudan 14 000 000 SEK
Öronmärkt stöd: 1. Burundi 6 000 000 SEK (Skydd av barn och WASH) 2. CAR 5 000 000 SEK (Rapid Response Mechanism/RRM) 3. DRK 10 000 000 SEK (Rapid Response to Movements of Population (RRMP)
B. Snabb responsmekanism i form av oallokerade medel: Det föreslås även ett stöd om 38 000 000 SEK för 2018 och 2 000 000 SEK per år för 2019, 2020 och 2021 som UNICEF kan rekvirera och använda efter godkännande från Sida, för nya eller förvärrade humanitära kriser.
C. Slutligen föreslås metod/tematiskt stöd till projekt som bidrar till att stärka den humanitära responsen, specifikt ökad deltagande av den drabbade befolkningen (AAP) i CAR men 3 200 000 SEK för 2018 och 2 300 000 SEK för 2019.
Det föreslås at Sida ska ingå två avtal med UNICEF i syfte att särskilja det stöd som går till de humanitära appellerna respektive metodstöd. Detta är i enlighet med önskemål från UNICEF i syfte att förenkla deras hantering.
Sidas stöd till UNICEF är baserat på FNs samordnade humanitära responsplaner (HRP) samt UNICEFs ’Humanitarian Action for Children' (HAC). Bidraget kommer att allokeras till UNICEF på landnivå med både öronmärkt eller o-öronmärkt stöd. Sida väljer att öronmärkta stödet till vissa kriser för att säkerställa att de sektorer eller komponenter med störst humanitära behoven enligt behovsanalysen adresseras. Inom det humanitära systemet är UNICEF en central aktör med ett särskilt mandat som riktar sig till barn och mödrar i konfliktsituationer eller naturkatastrofer. Genom stödet kommer organisationen därmed ge livräddande och livsuppehållande stöd till de mest utsatta grupperna med fokus på barn och kvinnor i humanitära situationer. Stödet kommer att inkludera nya akuta humanitära situationer, pågående samt eskalerande kriser.
Sidas stöd till UNICEF kommer förutom att bidra med humanitär finansiering för att bistå utsatta grupper i humanitära kriser även att bidra till samordnad och effektiv respons i de utvalda länderna. UNICEF ansvarar för att leda och samordna de globala klustren för nutrition, utbildning, vatten och sanitet samt har ansvar för skydd av barn.
UNICEF har framfört att tidig utbetalning av årliga bidrag för humanitära insatser är en förutsättning för att organisationen ska kunna ingå förpliktelser i form av anställning av personal och kunna påbörja den upphandling av de varor och tjänster som behövs för den humanitära responsen. UNICEF har en väl utvecklad logistik med lager i regionala depåer och har en roll i det humanitära systemet att även förse andra implementerande partners med varor. Humanitära kriser är till sin karaktär snabbt skiftande både geografiskt och i intensitet, UNICEF måste därför vara beredda att kunna flytta såväl personal som förnödenheter.
Sida delar UNICEFs bedömning att det föreligger ett behov av att kunna planera och förbereda insatser utan onödig fördröjning och bedömer därför att samtliga medel för projektet ska utbetalas ut omgående för att möjliggöra planering och uppstart av projektet till 1 januari 2018. Ett avsteg från Sidas vanliga rutiner om uppdelade betalningar bedöms motiverat.
Bedömningspromemorian har skrivits på engelska med anledning av att engelskspråkig personal i fält är delaktig i beredning och uppföljning av insatsen, i enlighet med Generaldirektörens beslut om Sidas språkvalsmatris med tillämpningsanvisningar från den 1 mars 2013.

To save lives and alleviate suffering for children in who's lives have been affected due to conflict and natural disasters worldwide; mainly in the sectors of nutrition, health, water and sanitation and hygiene, as well as in emergency education, child protection and gender-based violence (GBV).

tag.narrative: 17.17 - Encourage and promote effective public, public-private and civil society partnerships, building on the experience and resourcing strategies of partnerships

description.narrative: Sida has received the annual report for 2019 (30 June 2020) and we are happy to note that in the more than 20 different contexts the following examples of achievements are reported: In Cameroon UNICEF humanitarian assistance primarily focused on refugees who fled the armed conflict in Central African Republic (CAR) and their host communities, to IDPs caused by the ongoing crisis in the North West and South West of Cameroon and to persons displaced by Boko Haram attacks in Far North region inlcuding refugees and outsed restablished camps. - Nationally, 79 311 (target 65 064) children aged 6-59 months with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) were admitted for treatment where 137 additional primary health facilities were possible to include in this emergency response (compared to a target figure of 702). - Nationally, UNICEF implementing partners reached 54 240 target families/households with at least 1 long-lasting insecticidal nets or 83% of the target figure of 62 739 familieis/households. - 152 947 children (6 months to 15 years) were vaccinated against measles (target 266 492). - Funding shortfalls impacted the planned WASH results with only 22 000 people supported with sustainable access to safe drinking water against a taret of 110 000 while 23 456 people were assisted with access to adequate basic sanitation agianst a target of 75 000 pople. The WASH sector received an overall funding level of only 8% against the requirement. - Also in the education sector, low funding led to poor emergency education results in 2019. Over 5 900 girls and boys (3-17 years) receive learning materials, well below the target of 217 989. - With a bit more appropriate funding for child protection, 141 555 children were reached with psycho-social support including child friendly spaces, against a goal of 289 789. In Syria, despite the complex environment UNICEF worked to deliver humanitarian assistance within the Whole of Syria (WoS) approach. UNICEF focused on multi-sectoral response addressing Health, Nutrition, WASH, Education and Protection needs and Social Protection. This was 91% of target and was due to the constrained access in some areas of Idlib. - The expansion of vaccination services ensured that over 500 000 children under-1 received diphteria-tetanus-pertussis vaccination and over 3 million children were immunized against polio. - Access to services by vulnerable groups such as women and children were enhanced by the increasing use of mobile teams with female health workers in some of the hard to reach communities and IDP camps. - UNICEF supported the screening of about 1.8 million children under-5 and pregnant and lactating women for acute malnutrition. Of the total children screened, 11 498 were found to be affected by SAM and received life-saving treatment. - Emergency WASH interventions reached over 1 million people through the distribution of non-food items (NFIs) including family hygiene kits, soap and aqua tabs and installation of water tanks in camps, host communities and IDP shelters across the country. - To strengthen girls' and boys' coping mechanisms and resilience, UNICEF provided psychosocial support services to about 393 500 children (50% girls) through fixed and mobile modalities. The target was overachieved as services were provided to address needs arising from new displacements and expansion in Deir-ez-Zor, Al Hasakeh and Aleppo. In Nigeria, UNICEF delivered an integrated package of interventions to conflict-affected populations in the northeast and handed over a greater share of service delivery to partners whose capacity in the region is increasing: - UNICEF reached 249 776 people in Borno state with temporary access to safe water, primarily through water trucking in hard-to-reach areas and areas where geological issues do not allow for the construction of new water facilities. - In collaboration with the Borno and Adamawa states, UNICEF sustained access to safe water to 771 428 people in Borno and 1.7 million people in Adamawa. - UNICEF supported the release of 461 children (57 girls and 404 boys) in line with the action plan signed with relevant partners. UNICEF is also providing reintegration services to all released children. - 358 962 children received psychosocial support services (reached 100% of target) and worked to reunify 275 unaccompanied and separated children with their familieis, while 752 children benefitted from alternative care placement. - Birth registration results exceeded planned targets, for children under-5 there were 94% births registered (versus a target of 54%), while children under-1 were registered 99% (target 72%). - A number of 3 969 664 conflict-affected people were reached with integrated primary health care services (approximately half of which were under-5). This included curative care, preventive services and women supported with safe deliveries and post-natal care. - A number of 138 772 children (target 158 488) aged 6-59 months with SAM were admitted to therapeutic care for specified period where 95% recovered.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

New/additional funds to address COVID-19 Each year Sida undertakes a humanitarian allocation process (Humanitarian Crises Analysis/HCA) in which all humanitarian crises are analysed, and where the partners most relevant to respond to the identified needs are selected. Based on the overall analysis of UNICEF as a key partner, it is suggested to enter a new agreement the organization and provide support during the period 2018-2021, which is in line with the new UNICEF Strategic Plan 2018-2021. UNICEF will continue to receive an unearmarked allocation (38 000 000 SEK) for ongoing, revised or new operations in accordance with the objectives of the Humanitarian programmes (UN Appeals and UNICEF Humanitarian Action for Children/HAC). For 2018, an additional amount of 202 000 000 SEK will be made available for specific humanitarian programmes in 15 crises which will be presented below. Furthermore, support will be provided to technical projects and programmes that may be outside the UNICEF HAC Appeals but that contribute to the strengthening and improving activities and cross cutting issues related to humanitarian appeals.
An amount of SEK 3 200 000 for 2018 and SEK 2 300 000 for 2019 will also be utilized for the inter-agency collective service for community engagement and accountability project proposal which is hosted by UNICEF on the behalf of the Communication with Communities Working Group (CwCWG). The funds will be directed for the Central African Republic (CAR) context. This project aims to improve the humanitarian response in CAR by strengthening the accountability to the affected population (AAP).

Det aktuella stödet till UNICEF i 15 länder/kriser baseras på Sidas humanitära allokering, som färdigställdes under slutet av 2017. Stödet till UNICEF bedöms relevant för att uppnå målen i Strategi för Sveriges humanitära bistånd genom Sida 2017-2020.
Under 2017 uppgick det totala utbetalda Sida humanitära bidraget till UNICEF till 351 000 000 SEK. Det totala initiala bidrag som föreslås för 2018 uppgår till 243 200 000 SEK och är uppdelat på de följande kategorierna:
A. Landspecifikt stöd: Den förslagna landfördelningen för 2018 (identifierade under allokeringsprocessen) omfattar totalt SEK 202 000 000 med stöd till UNICEFs humanitära arbete inom sektorerna hälsa, nutrition, utbildning, barnskyddsfrågor, könsrelaterat våld och vatten och sanitet:
O-öronmärkt stöd: 1. Syrien krisen 25 000 000 SEK 2. Somaliakrisen 14 000 000 SEK 3. Demokratiska Folk Republiken Korea 8 000 000 SEK 4. Jemen 30 000 000 SEK 5. Niger 6 000 000 SEK 6. Nigeria 25 000 000 SEK 7. Irak 13 000 000 SEK 8. Etiopien 25 000 000 SEK 9. Mali 7 000 000 SEK 10. Tchad 4 000 000 SEK 11. Sudan 10 000 000 SEK 12. Sydsudan 14 000 000 SEK
Öronmärkt stöd: 1. Burundi 6 000 000 SEK (Skydd av barn och WASH) 2. CAR 5 000 000 SEK (Rapid Response Mechanism/RRM) 3. DRK 10 000 000 SEK (Rapid Response to Movements of Population (RRMP)
B. Snabb responsmekanism i form av oallokerade medel: Det föreslås även ett stöd om 38 000 000 SEK för 2018 och 2 000 000 SEK per år för 2019, 2020 och 2021 som UNICEF kan rekvirera och använda efter godkännande från Sida, för nya eller förvärrade humanitära kriser.
C. Slutligen föreslås metod/tematiskt stöd till projekt som bidrar till att stärka den humanitära responsen, specifikt ökad deltagande av den drabbade befolkningen (AAP) i CAR men 3 200 000 SEK för 2018 och 2 300 000 SEK för 2019.
Det föreslås at Sida ska ingå två avtal med UNICEF i syfte att särskilja det stöd som går till de humanitära appellerna respektive metodstöd. Detta är i enlighet med önskemål från UNICEF i syfte att förenkla deras hantering.
Sidas stöd till UNICEF är baserat på FNs samordnade humanitära responsplaner (HRP) samt UNICEFs ’Humanitarian Action for Children' (HAC). Bidraget kommer att allokeras till UNICEF på landnivå med både öronmärkt eller o-öronmärkt stöd. Sida väljer att öronmärkta stödet till vissa kriser för att säkerställa att de sektorer eller komponenter med störst humanitära behoven enligt behovsanalysen adresseras. Inom det humanitära systemet är UNICEF en central aktör med ett särskilt mandat som riktar sig till barn och mödrar i konfliktsituationer eller naturkatastrofer. Genom stödet kommer organisationen därmed ge livräddande och livsuppehållande stöd till de mest utsatta grupperna med fokus på barn och kvinnor i humanitära situationer. Stödet kommer att inkludera nya akuta humanitära situationer, pågående samt eskalerande kriser.
Sidas stöd till UNICEF kommer förutom att bidra med humanitär finansiering för att bistå utsatta grupper i humanitära kriser även att bidra till samordnad och effektiv respons i de utvalda länderna. UNICEF ansvarar för att leda och samordna de globala klustren för nutrition, utbildning, vatten och sanitet samt har ansvar för skydd av barn.
UNICEF har framfört att tidig utbetalning av årliga bidrag för humanitära insatser är en förutsättning för att organisationen ska kunna ingå förpliktelser i form av anställning av personal och kunna påbörja den upphandling av de varor och tjänster som behövs för den humanitära responsen. UNICEF har en väl utvecklad logistik med lager i regionala depåer och har en roll i det humanitära systemet att även förse andra implementerande partners med varor. Humanitära kriser är till sin karaktär snabbt skiftande både geografiskt och i intensitet, UNICEF måste därför vara beredda att kunna flytta såväl personal som förnödenheter.
Sida delar UNICEFs bedömning att det föreligger ett behov av att kunna planera och förbereda insatser utan onödig fördröjning och bedömer därför att samtliga medel för projektet ska utbetalas ut omgående för att möjliggöra planering och uppstart av projektet till 1 januari 2018. Ett avsteg från Sidas vanliga rutiner om uppdelade betalningar bedöms motiverat.
Bedömningspromemorian har skrivits på engelska med anledning av att engelskspråkig personal i fält är delaktig i beredning och uppföljning av insatsen, i enlighet med Generaldirektörens beslut om Sidas språkvalsmatris med tillämpningsanvisningar från den 1 mars 2013.

To save lives and alleviate suffering for children in who's lives have been affected due to conflict and natural disasters worldwide; mainly in the sectors of nutrition, health, water and sanitation and hygiene, as well as in emergency education, child protection and gender-based violence (GBV).

tag.narrative: 17.17 - Encourage and promote effective public, public-private and civil society partnerships, building on the experience and resourcing strategies of partnerships
17.17 - Encourage and promote effective public, public-private and civil society partnerships, building on the experience and resourcing strategies of partnerships.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: Sida has received the annual report for 2019 (30 June 2020) and we are happy to note that in the more than 20 different contexts the following examples of achievements are reported: In Cameroon UNICEF humanitarian assistance primarily focused on refugees who fled the armed conflict in Central African Republic (CAR) and their host communities, to IDPs caused by the ongoing crisis in the North West and South West of Cameroon and to persons displaced by Boko Haram attacks in Far North region inlcuding refugees and outsed restablished camps. - Nationally, 79 311 (target 65 064) children aged 6-59 months with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) were admitted for treatment where 137 additional primary health facilities were possible to include in this emergency response (compared to a target figure of 702). - Nationally, UNICEF implementing partners reached 54 240 target families/households with at least 1 long-lasting insecticidal nets or 83% of the target figure of 62 739 familieis/households. - 152 947 children (6 months to 15 years) were vaccinated against measles (target 266 492). - Funding shortfalls impacted the planned WASH results with only 22 000 people supported with sustainable access to safe drinking water against a taret of 110 000 while 23 456 people were assisted with access to adequate basic sanitation agianst a target of 75 000 pople. The WASH sector received an overall funding level of only 8% against the requirement. - Also in the education sector, low funding led to poor emergency education results in 2019. Over 5 900 girls and boys (3-17 years) receive learning materials, well below the target of 217 989. - With a bit more appropriate funding for child protection, 141 555 children were reached with psycho-social support including child friendly spaces, against a goal of 289 789. In Syria, despite the complex environment UNICEF worked to deliver humanitarian assistance within the Whole of Syria (WoS) approach. UNICEF focused on multi-sectoral response addressing Health, Nutrition, WASH, Education and Protection needs and Social Protection. UNICEF has been progressively strengthening its focus on the longer term by scaling-up resilience building interventions and will continue to move in this direction: - UNICEF supported over 2 million women and children to receive primary health care consultations across Syria. This was 91% of target and was due to the constrained access in some areas of Idlib. - The expansion of vaccination services ensured that over 500 000 children under-1 received diphteria-tetanus-pertussis vaccination and over 3 million children were immunized against polio. - Access to services by vulnerable groups such as women and children were enhanced by the increasing use of mobile teams with female health workers in some of the hard to reach communities and IDP camps. - UNICEF supported the screening of about 1.8 million children under-5 and pregnant and lactating women for acute malnutrition. Of the total children screened, 11 498 were found to be affected by SAM and received life-saving treatment. - Emergency WASH interventions reached over 1 million people through the distribution of non-food items (NFIs) including family hygiene kits, soap and aqua tabs and installation of water tanks in camps, host communities and IDP shelters across the country. - To strengthen girls' and boys' coping mechanisms and resilience, UNICEF provided psychosocial support services to about 393 500 children (50% girls) through fixed and mobile modalities. The target was overachieved as services were provided to address needs arising from new displacements and expansion in Deir-ez-Zor, Al Hasakeh and Aleppo. In Nigeria, UNICEF delivered an integrated package of interventions to conflict-affected populations in the northeast and handed over a greater share of service delivery to partners whose capacity in the region is increasing: - UNICEF reached 249 776 people in Borno state with temporary access to safe water, primarily through water trucking in hard-to-reach areas and areas where geological issues do not allow for the construction of new water facilities. - In collaboration with the Borno and Adamawa states, UNICEF sustained access to safe water to 771 428 people in Borno and 1.7 million people in Adamawa. - UNICEF supported the release of 461 children (57 girls and 404 boys) in line with the action plan signed with relevant partners. UNICEF is also providing reintegration services to all released children. - 358 962 children received psychosocial support services (reached 100% of target) and worked to reunify 275 unaccompanied and separated children with their familieis, while 752 children benefitted from alternative care placement. - Birth registration results exceeded planned targets, for children under-5 there were 94% births registered (versus a target of 54%), while children under-1 were registered 99% (target 72%). - A number of 3 969 664 conflict-affected people were reached with integrated primary health care services (approximately half of which were under-5). This included curative care, preventive services and women supported with safe deliveries and post-natal care. - A number of 138 772 children (target 158 488) aged 6-59 months with SAM were admitted to therapeutic care for specified period where 95% recovered.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

New/additional funds to address COVID-19 Each year Sida undertakes a humanitarian allocation process (Humanitarian Crises Analysis/HCA) in which all humanitarian crises are analysed, and where the partners most relevant to respond to the identified needs are selected. Based on the overall analysis of UNICEF as a key partner, it is suggested to enter a new agreement the organization and provide support during the period 2018-2021, which is in line with the new UNICEF Strategic Plan 2018-2021. UNICEF will continue to receive an unearmarked allocation (38 000 000 SEK) for ongoing, revised or new operations in accordance with the objectives of the Humanitarian programmes (UN Appeals and UNICEF Humanitarian Action for Children/HAC). For 2018, an additional amount of 202 000 000 SEK will be made available for specific humanitarian programmes in 15 crises which will be presented below. Furthermore, support will be provided to technical projects and programmes that may be outside the UNICEF HAC Appeals but that contribute to the strengthening and improving activities and cross cutting issues related to humanitarian appeals.
An amount of SEK 3 200 000 for 2018 and SEK 2 300 000 for 2019 will also be utilized for the inter-agency collective service for community engagement and accountability project proposal which is hosted by UNICEF on the behalf of the Communication with Communities Working Group (CwCWG). The funds will be directed for the Central African Republic (CAR) context. This project aims to improve the humanitarian response in CAR by strengthening the accountability to the affected population (AAP).

Ett avsteg från Sidas vanliga rutiner om uppdelade betalningar bedöms motiverat.
Bedömningspromemorian har skrivits på engelska med anledning av att engelskspråkig personal i fält är delaktig i beredning och uppföljning av insatsen, i enlighet med Generaldirektörens beslut om Sidas språkvalsmatris med tillämpningsanvisningar från den 1 mars 2013.

To save lives and alleviate suffering for children in who's lives have been affected due to conflict and natural disasters worldwide; mainly in the sectors of nutrition, health, water and sanitation and hygiene, as well as in emergency education, child protection and gender-based violence (GBV).

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: Sida has received the annual report for 2019 (30 June 2020) and we are happy to note that in the more than 20 different contexts the following examples of achievements are reported: In Cameroon UNICEF humanitarian assistance primarily focused on refugees who fled the armed conflict in Central African Republic (CAR) and their host communities, to IDPs caused by the ongoing crisis in the North West and South West of Cameroon and to persons displaced by Boko Haram attacks in Far North region inlcuding refugees and outsed restablished camps. - Nationally, 79 311 (target 65 064) children aged 6-59 months with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) were admitted for treatment where 137 additional primary health facilities were possible to include in this emergency response (compared to a target figure of 702). - Nationally, UNICEF implementing partners reached 54 240 target families/households with at least 1 long-lasting insecticidal nets or 83% of the target figure of 62 739 familieis/households. - 152 947 children (6 months to 15 years) were vaccinated against measles (target 266 492). - Funding shortfalls impacted the planned WASH results with only 22 000 people supported with sustainable access to safe drinking water against a taret of 110 000 while 23 456 people were assisted with access to adequate basic sanitation agianst a target of 75 000 pople. The WASH sector received an overall funding level of only 8% against the requirement. - Also in the education sector, low funding led to poor emergency education results in 2019. Over 5 900 girls and boys (3-17 years) receive learning materials, well below the target of 217 989. - With a bit more appropriate funding for child protection, 141 555 children were reached with psycho-social support including child friendly spaces, against a goal of 289 789. In Syria, despite the complex environment UNICEF worked to deliver humanitarian assistance within the Whole of Syria (WoS) approach. UNICEF focused on multi-sectoral response addressing Health, Nutrition, WASH, Education and Protection needs and Social Protection. UNICEF has been progressively strengthening its focus on the longer term by scaling-up resilience building interventions and will continue to move in this direction: - UNICEF supported over 2 million women and children to receive primary health care consultations across Syria. This was 91% of target and was due to the constrained access in some areas of Idlib. - The expansion of vaccination services ensured that over 500 000 children under-1 received diphteria-tetanus-pertussis vaccination and over 3 million children were immunized against polio. - Access to services by vulnerable groups such as women and children were enhanced by the increasing use of mobile teams with female health workers in some of the hard to reach communities and IDP camps. - UNICEF supported the screening of about 1.8 million children under-5 and pregnant and lactating women for acute malnutrition. Of the total children screened, 11 498 were found to be affected by SAM and received life-saving treatment. - Emergency WASH interventions reached over 1 million people through the distribution of non-food items (NFIs) including family hygiene kits, soap and aqua tabs and installation of water tanks in camps, host communities and IDP shelters across the country. - To strengthen girls' and boys' coping mechanisms and resilience, UNICEF provided psychosocial support services to about 393 500 children (50% girls) through fixed and mobile modalities. The target was overachieved as services were provided to address needs arising from new displacements and expansion in Deir-ez-Zor, Al Hasakeh and Aleppo. In Nigeria, UNICEF delivered an integrated package of interventions to conflict-affected populations in the northeast and handed over a greater share of service delivery to partners whose capacity in the region is increasing: - UNICEF reached 249 776 people in Borno state with temporary access to safe water, primarily through water trucking in hard-to-reach areas and areas where geological issues do not allow for the construction of new water facilities. - In collaboration with the Borno and Adamawa states, UNICEF sustained access to safe water to 771 428 people in Borno and 1.7 million people in Adamawa. - UNICEF supported the release of 461 children (57 girls and 404 boys) in line with the action plan signed with relevant partners. UNICEF is also providing reintegration services to all released children. - 358 962 children received psychosocial support services (reached 100% of target) and worked to reunify 275 unaccompanied and separated children with their familieis, while 752 children benefitted from alternative care placement. - Birth registration results exceeded planned targets, for children under-5 there were 94% births registered (versus a target of 54%), while children under-1 were registered 99% (target 72%). - A number of 3 969 664 conflict-affected people were reached with integrated primary health care services (approximately half of which were under-5). This included curative care, preventive services and women supported with safe deliveries and post-natal care. - A number of 138 772 children (target 158 488) aged 6-59 months with SAM were admitted to therapeutic care for specified period where 95% recovered.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

New/additional funds to address COVID-19 Each year Sida undertakes a humanitarian allocation process (Humanitarian Crises Analysis/HCA) in which all humanitarian crises are analysed, and where the partners most relevant to respond to the identified needs are selected. Based on the overall analysis of UNICEF as a key partner, it is suggested to enter a new agreement the organization and provide support during the period 2018-2021, which is in line with the new UNICEF Strategic Plan 2018-2021. UNICEF will continue to receive an unearmarked allocation (38 000 000 SEK) for ongoing, revised or new operations in accordance with the objectives of the Humanitarian programmes (UN Appeals and UNICEF Humanitarian Action for Children/HAC). For 2018, an additional amount of 202 000 000 SEK will be made available for specific humanitarian programmes in 15 crises which will be presented below. Furthermore, support will be provided to technical projects and programmes that may be outside the UNICEF HAC Appeals but that contribute to the strengthening and improving activities and cross cutting issues related to humanitarian appeals.
An amount of SEK 3 200 000 for 2018 and SEK 2 300 000 for 2019 will also be utilized for the inter-agency collective service for community engagement and accountability project proposal which is hosted by UNICEF on the behalf of the Communication with Communities Working Group (CwCWG). The funds will be directed for the Central African Republic (CAR) context. This project aims to improve the humanitarian response in CAR by strengthening the accountability to the affected population (AAP).

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 Den globala trenden med ökade humanitära behov fortsätter under 2018 och i början på året beräknas 90,9 miljoner människor i 26 länder vara i behov av humanitärt stöd och FN:s appeller uppgår till 22,5 miljarder dollar.
Sida genomför årligen en humanitär allokeringsprocess då de omkring 15 stora pågående humanitära kriserna analyseras utifrån de humanitära behoven och där de mest relevanta av strategiska partnerorganisationer identifieras. Det aktuella stödet till UNICEF i 15 länder/kriser baseras på Sidas humanitära allokering, som färdigställdes under slutet av 2017. Stödet till UNICEF bedöms relevant för att uppnå målen i Strategi för Sveriges humanitära bistånd genom Sida 2017-2020.
Under 2017 uppgick det totala utbetalda Sida humanitära bidraget till UNICEF till 351 000 000 SEK. Det totala initiala bidrag som föreslås för 2018 uppgår till 243 200 000 SEK och är uppdelat på de följande kategorierna:
A. Landspecifikt stöd: Den förslagna landfördelningen för 2018 (identifierade under allokeringsprocessen) omfattar totalt SEK 202 000 000 med stöd till UNICEFs humanitära arbete inom sektorerna hälsa, nutrition, utbildning, barnskyddsfrågor, könsrelaterat våld och vatten och sanitet:
O-öronmärkt stöd: 1. Syrien krisen 25 000 000 SEK 2. Somaliakrisen 14 000 000 SEK 3. Demokratiska Folk Republiken Korea 8 000 000 SEK 4. Jemen 30 000 000 SEK 5. Niger 6 000 000 SEK 6. Nigeria 25 000 000 SEK 7. Irak 13 000 000 SEK 8. Etiopien 25 000 000 SEK 9. Mali 7 000 000 SEK 10. Tchad 4 000 000 SEK 11. Sudan 10 000 000 SEK 12. Sydsudan 14 000 000 SEK
Öronmärkt stöd: 1. Burundi 6 000 000 SEK (Skydd av barn och WASH) 2. CAR 5 000 000 SEK (Rapid Response Mechanism/RRM) 3. DRK 10 000 000 SEK (Rapid Response to Movements of Population (RRMP)
B. Snabb responsmekanism i form av oallokerade medel: Det föreslås även ett stöd om 38 000 000 SEK för 2018 och 2 000 000 SEK per år för 2019, 2020 och 2021 som UNICEF kan rekvirera och använda efter godkännande från Sida, för nya eller förvärrade humanitära kriser.
C. Slutligen föreslås metod/tematiskt stöd till projekt som bidrar till att stärka den humanitära responsen, specifikt ökad deltagande av den drabbade befolkningen (AAP) i CAR men 3 200 000 SEK för 2018 och 2 300 000 SEK för 2019.
Det föreslås at Sida ska ingå två avtal med UNICEF i syfte att särskilja det stöd som går till de humanitära appellerna respektive metodstöd. Detta är i enlighet med önskemål från UNICEF i syfte att förenkla deras hantering.
Sidas stöd till UNICEF är baserat på FNs samordnade humanitära responsplaner (HRP) samt UNICEFs ’Humanitarian Action for Children' (HAC). Bidraget kommer att allokeras till UNICEF på landnivå med både öronmärkt eller o-öronmärkt stöd. Sida väljer att öronmärkta stödet till vissa kriser för att säkerställa att de sektorer eller komponenter med störst humanitära behoven enligt behovsanalysen adresseras. Inom det humanitära systemet är UNICEF en central aktör med ett särskilt mandat som riktar sig till barn och mödrar i konfliktsituationer eller naturkatastrofer. Genom stödet kommer organisationen därmed ge livräddande och livsuppehållande stöd till de mest utsatta grupperna med fokus på barn och kvinnor i humanitära situationer. Stödet kommer att inkludera nya akuta humanitära situationer, pågående samt eskalerande kriser.
Sidas stöd till UNICEF kommer förutom att bidra med humanitär finansiering för att bistå utsatta grupper i humanitära kriser även att bidra till samordnad och effektiv respons i de utvalda länderna. UNICEF ansvarar för att leda och samordna de globala klustren för nutrition, utbildning, vatten och sanitet samt har ansvar för skydd av barn.
UNICEF har framfört att tidig utbetalning av årliga bidrag för humanitära insatser är en förutsättning för att organisationen ska kunna ingå förpliktelser i form av anställning av personal och kunna påbörja den upphandling av de varor och tjänster som behövs för den humanitära responsen. UNICEF har en väl utvecklad logistik med lager i regionala depåer och har en roll i det humanitära systemet att även förse andra implementerande partners med varor. Humanitära kriser är till sin karaktär snabbt skiftande både geografiskt och i intensitet, UNICEF måste därför vara beredda att kunna flytta såväl personal som förnödenheter.
Sida delar UNICEFs bedömning att det föreligger ett behov av att kunna planera och förbereda insatser utan onödig fördröjning och bedömer därför att samtliga medel för projektet ska utbetalas ut omgående för att möjliggöra planering och uppstart av projektet till 1 januari 2018. Ett avsteg från Sidas vanliga rutiner om uppdelade betalningar bedöms motiverat.
Bedömningspromemorian har skrivits på engelska med anledning av att engelskspråkig personal i fält är delaktig i beredning och uppföljning av insatsen, i enlighet med Generaldirektörens beslut om Sidas språkvalsmatris med tillämpningsanvisningar från den 1 mars 2013.

To save lives and alleviate suffering for children in who's lives have been affected due to conflict and natural disasters worldwide; mainly in the sectors of nutrition, health, water and sanitation and hygiene, as well as in emergency education, child protection and gender-based violence (GBV).
