Sida delar UNICEFs bedömning att det föreligger ett behov av att kunna planera och förbereda insatser utan onödig fördröjning och bedömer därför att samtliga medel för projektet ska utbetalas ut omgående för att möjliggöra planering och uppstart av projektet till 1 januari 2018. Ett avsteg från Sidas vanliga rutiner om uppdelade betalningar bedöms motiverat.
Bedömningspromemorian har skrivits på engelska med anledning av att engelskspråkig personal i fält är delaktig i beredning och uppföljning av insatsen, i enlighet med Generaldirektörens beslut om Sidas språkvalsmatris med tillämpningsanvisningar från den 1 mars 2013.

To save lives and alleviate suffering for children in who's lives have been affected due to conflict and natural disasters worldwide; mainly in the sectors of nutrition, health, water and sanitation and hygiene, as well as in emergency education, child protection and gender-based violence (GBV).

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: Sida has received the annual report for 2019 (30 June 2020) and we are happy to note that in the more than 20 different contexts the following examples of achievements are reported: In Cameroon UNICEF humanitarian assistance primarily focused on refugees who fled the armed conflict in Central African Republic (CAR) and their host communities, to IDPs caused by the ongoing crisis in the North West and South West of Cameroon and to persons displaced by Boko Haram attacks in Far North region inlcuding refugees and outsed restablished camps. - Nationally, 79 311 (target 65 064) children aged 6-59 months with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) were admitted for treatment where 137 additional primary health facilities were possible to include in this emergency response (compared to a target figure of 702). - Nationally, UNICEF implementing partners reached 54 240 target families/households with at least 1 long-lasting insecticidal nets or 83% of the target figure of 62 739 familieis/households. - 152 947 children (6 months to 15 years) were vaccinated against measles (target 266 492). - Funding shortfalls impacted the planned WASH results with only 22 000 people supported with sustainable access to safe drinking water against a taret of 110 000 while 23 456 people were assisted with access to adequate basic sanitation agianst a target of 75 000 pople. The WASH sector received an overall funding level of only 8% against the requirement. - Also in the education sector, low funding led to poor emergency education results in 2019. Over 5 900 girls and boys (3-17 years) receive learning materials, well below the target of 217 989. - With a bit more appropriate funding for child protection, 141 555 children were reached with psycho-social support including child friendly spaces, against a goal of 289 789. In Syria, despite the complex environment UNICEF worked to deliver humanitarian assistance within the Whole of Syria (WoS) approach. UNICEF focused on multi-sectoral response addressing Health, Nutrition, WASH, Education and Protection needs and Social Protection. UNICEF has been progressively strengthening its focus on the longer term by scaling-up resilience building interventions and will continue to move in this direction: - UNICEF supported over 2 million women and children to receive primary health care consultations across Syria. This was 91% of target and was due to the constrained access in some areas of Idlib. - The expansion of vaccination services ensured that over 500 000 children under-1 received diphteria-tetanus-pertussis vaccination and over 3 million children were immunized against polio. - Access to services by vulnerable groups such as women and children were enhanced by the increasing use of mobile teams with female health workers in some of the hard to reach communities and IDP camps. - UNICEF supported the screening of about 1.8 million children under-5 and pregnant and lactating women for acute malnutrition. Of the total children screened, 11 498 were found to be affected by SAM and received life-saving treatment. - Emergency WASH interventions reached over 1 million people through the distribution of non-food items (NFIs) including family hygiene kits, soap and aqua tabs and installation of water tanks in camps, host communities and IDP shelters across the country. - To strengthen girls' and boys' coping mechanisms and resilience, UNICEF provided psychosocial support services to about 393 500 children (50% girls) through fixed and mobile modalities. The target was overachieved as services were provided to address needs arising from new displacements and expansion in Deir-ez-Zor, Al Hasakeh and Aleppo. In Nigeria, UNICEF delivered an integrated package of interventions to conflict-affected populations in the northeast and handed over a greater share of service delivery to partners whose capacity in the region is increasing: - UNICEF reached 249 776 people in Borno state with temporary access to safe water, primarily through water trucking in hard-to-reach areas and areas where geological issues do not allow for the construction of new water facilities. - In collaboration with the Borno and Adamawa states, UNICEF sustained access to safe water to 771 428 people in Borno and 1.7 million people in Adamawa. - UNICEF supported the release of 461 children (57 girls and 404 boys) in line with the action plan signed with relevant partners. UNICEF is also providing reintegration services to all released children. - 358 962 children received psychosocial support services (reached 100% of target) and worked to reunify 275 unaccompanied and separated children with their familieis, while 752 children benefitted from alternative care placement. - Birth registration results exceeded planned targets, for children under-5 there were 94% births registered (versus a target of 54%), while children under-1 were registered 99% (target 72%). - A number of 3 969 664 conflict-affected people were reached with integrated primary health care services (approximately half of which were under-5). This included curative care, preventive services and women supported with safe deliveries and post-natal care. - A number of 138 772 children (target 158 488) aged 6-59 months with SAM were admitted to therapeutic care for specified period where 95% recovered.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

New/additional funds to address COVID-19 Each year Sida undertakes a humanitarian allocation process (Humanitarian Crises Analysis/HCA) in which all humanitarian crises are analysed, and where the partners most relevant to respond to the identified needs are selected. Based on the overall analysis of UNICEF as a key partner, it is suggested to enter a new agreement the organization and provide support during the period 2018-2021, which is in line with the new UNICEF Strategic Plan 2018-2021. UNICEF will continue to receive an unearmarked allocation (38 000 000 SEK) for ongoing, revised or new operations in accordance with the objectives of the Humanitarian programmes (UN Appeals and UNICEF Humanitarian Action for Children/HAC). For 2018, an additional amount of 202 000 000 SEK will be made available for specific humanitarian programmes in 15 crises which will be presented below. Furthermore, support will be provided to technical projects and programmes that may be outside the UNICEF HAC Appeals but that contribute to the strengthening and improving activities and cross cutting issues related to humanitarian appeals.
An amount of SEK 3 200 000 for 2018 and SEK 2 300 000 for 2019 will also be utilized for the inter-agency collective service for community engagement and accountability project proposal which is hosted by UNICEF on the behalf of the Communication with Communities Working Group (CwCWG). The funds will be directed for the Central African Republic (CAR) context. This project aims to improve the humanitarian response in CAR by strengthening the accountability to the affected population (AAP).

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 Den globala trenden med ökade humanitära behov fortsätter under 2018 och i början på året beräknas 90,9 miljoner människor i 26 länder vara i behov av humanitärt stöd och FN:s appeller uppgår till 22,5 miljarder dollar.
Sida genomför årligen en humanitär allokeringsprocess då de omkring 15 stora pågående humanitära kriserna analyseras utifrån de humanitära behoven och där de mest relevanta av strategiska partnerorganisationer identifieras. Det aktuella stödet till UNICEF i 15 länder/kriser baseras på Sidas humanitära allokering, som färdigställdes under slutet av 2017. Stödet till UNICEF bedöms relevant för att uppnå målen i Strategi för Sveriges humanitära bistånd genom Sida 2017-2020.
Under 2017 uppgick det totala utbetalda Sida humanitära bidraget till UNICEF till 351 000 000 SEK. Det totala initiala bidrag som föreslås för 2018 uppgår till 243 200 000 SEK och är uppdelat på de följande kategorierna:
A. Landspecifikt stöd: Den förslagna landfördelningen för 2018 (identifierade under allokeringsprocessen) omfattar totalt SEK 202 000 000 med stöd till UNICEFs humanitära arbete inom sektorerna hälsa, nutrition, utbildning, barnskyddsfrågor, könsrelaterat våld och vatten och sanitet:
O-öronmärkt stöd: 1. Syrien krisen 25 000 000 SEK 2. Somaliakrisen 14 000 000 SEK 3. Demokratiska Folk Republiken Korea 8 000 000 SEK 4. Jemen 30 000 000 SEK 5. Niger 6 000 000 SEK 6. Nigeria 25 000 000 SEK 7. Irak 13 000 000 SEK 8. Etiopien 25 000 000 SEK 9. Mali 7 000 000 SEK 10. Tchad 4 000 000 SEK 11. Sudan 10 000 000 SEK 12. Sydsudan 14 000 000 SEK
Öronmärkt stöd: 1. Burundi 6 000 000 SEK (Skydd av barn och WASH) 2. CAR 5 000 000 SEK (Rapid Response Mechanism/RRM) 3. DRK 10 000 000 SEK (Rapid Response to Movements of Population (RRMP)
B. Snabb responsmekanism i form av oallokerade medel: Det föreslås även ett stöd om 38 000 000 SEK för 2018 och 2 000 000 SEK per år för 2019, 2020 och 2021 som UNICEF kan rekvirera och använda efter godkännande från Sida, för nya eller förvärrade humanitära kriser.
C. Slutligen föreslås metod/tematiskt stöd till projekt som bidrar till att stärka den humanitära responsen, specifikt ökad deltagande av den drabbade befolkningen (AAP) i CAR men 3 200 000 SEK för 2018 och 2 300 000 SEK för 2019.
Det föreslås at Sida ska ingå två avtal med UNICEF i syfte att särskilja det stöd som går till de humanitära appellerna respektive metodstöd. Detta är i enlighet med önskemål från UNICEF i syfte att förenkla deras hantering.
Sidas stöd till UNICEF är baserat på FNs samordnade humanitära responsplaner (HRP) samt UNICEFs ’Humanitarian Action for Children' (HAC). Bidraget kommer att allokeras till UNICEF på landnivå med både öronmärkt eller o-öronmärkt stöd. Sida väljer att öronmärkta stödet till vissa kriser för att säkerställa att de sektorer eller komponenter med störst humanitära behoven enligt behovsanalysen adresseras. Inom det humanitära systemet är UNICEF en central aktör med ett särskilt mandat som riktar sig till barn och mödrar i konfliktsituationer eller naturkatastrofer. Genom stödet kommer organisationen därmed ge livräddande och livsuppehållande stöd till de mest utsatta grupperna med fokus på barn och kvinnor i humanitära situationer. Stödet kommer att inkludera nya akuta humanitära situationer, pågående samt eskalerande kriser.
Sidas stöd till UNICEF kommer förutom att bidra med humanitär finansiering för att bistå utsatta grupper i humanitära kriser även att bidra till samordnad och effektiv respons i de utvalda länderna. UNICEF ansvarar för att leda och samordna de globala klustren för nutrition, utbildning, vatten och sanitet samt har ansvar för skydd av barn.
UNICEF har framfört att tidig utbetalning av årliga bidrag för humanitära insatser är en förutsättning för att organisationen ska kunna ingå förpliktelser i form av anställning av personal och kunna påbörja den upphandling av de varor och tjänster som behövs för den humanitära responsen. UNICEF har en väl utvecklad logistik med lager i regionala depåer och har en roll i det humanitära systemet att även förse andra implementerande partners med varor. Humanitära kriser är till sin karaktär snabbt skiftande både geografiskt och i intensitet, UNICEF måste därför vara beredda att kunna flytta såväl personal som förnödenheter.
Sida delar UNICEFs bedömning att det föreligger ett behov av att kunna planera och förbereda insatser utan onödig fördröjning och bedömer därför att samtliga medel för projektet ska utbetalas ut omgående för att möjliggöra planering och uppstart av projektet till 1 januari 2018. Ett avsteg från Sidas vanliga rutiner om uppdelade betalningar bedöms motiverat.
Bedömningspromemorian har skrivits på engelska med anledning av att engelskspråkig personal i fält är delaktig i beredning och uppföljning av insatsen, i enlighet med Generaldirektörens beslut om Sidas språkvalsmatris med tillämpningsanvisningar från den 1 mars 2013.

To save lives and alleviate suffering for children in who's lives have been affected due to conflict and natural disasters worldwide; mainly in the sectors of nutrition, health, water and sanitation and hygiene, as well as in emergency education, child protection and gender-based violence (GBV).

UNICEF is also providing reintegration services to all released children. - 358 962 children received psychosocial support services (reached 100% of target) and worked to reunify 275 unaccompanied and separated children with their familieis, while 752 children benefitted from alternative care placement. - Birth registration results exceeded planned targets, for children under-5 there were 94% births registered (versus a target of 54%), while children under-1 were registered 99% (target 72%). - A number of 3 969 664 conflict-affected people were reached with integrated primary health care services (approximately half of which were under-5). This included curative care, preventive services and women supported with safe deliveries and post-natal care. - A number of 138 772 children (target 158 488) aged 6-59 months with SAM were admitted to therapeutic care for specified period where 95% recovered.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

New/additional funds to address COVID-19 Each year Sida undertakes a humanitarian allocation process (Humanitarian Crises Analysis/HCA) in which all humanitarian crises are analysed, and where the partners most relevant to respond to the identified needs are selected. Based on the overall analysis of UNICEF as a key partner, it is suggested to enter a new agreement the organization and provide support during the period 2018-2021, which is in line with the new UNICEF Strategic Plan 2018-2021. UNICEF will continue to receive an unearmarked allocation (38 000 000 SEK) for ongoing, revised or new operations in accordance with the objectives of the Humanitarian programmes (UN Appeals and UNICEF Humanitarian Action for Children/HAC). For 2018, an additional amount of 202 000 000 SEK will be made available for specific humanitarian programmes in 15 crises which will be presented below. Furthermore, support will be provided to technical projects and programmes that may be outside the UNICEF HAC Appeals but that contribute to the strengthening and improving activities and cross cutting issues related to humanitarian appeals.
An amount of SEK 3 200 000 for 2018 and SEK 2 300 000 for 2019 will also be utilized for the inter-agency collective service for community engagement and accountability project proposal which is hosted by UNICEF on the behalf of the Communication with Communities Working Group (CwCWG). The funds will be directed for the Central African Republic (CAR) context. This project aims to improve the humanitarian response in CAR by strengthening the accountability to the affected population (AAP).

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 Den globala trenden med ökade humanitära behov fortsätter under 2018 och i början på året beräknas 90,9 miljoner människor i 26 länder vara i behov av humanitärt stöd och FN:s appeller uppgår till 22,5 miljarder dollar.
Sida genomför årligen en humanitär allokeringsprocess då de omkring 15 stora pågående humanitära kriserna analyseras utifrån de humanitära behoven och där de mest relevanta av strategiska partnerorganisationer identifieras. Det aktuella stödet till UNICEF i 15 länder/kriser baseras på Sidas humanitära allokering, som färdigställdes under slutet av 2017. Stödet till UNICEF bedöms relevant för att uppnå målen i Strategi för Sveriges humanitära bistånd genom Sida 2017-2020.
Under 2017 uppgick det totala utbetalda Sida humanitära bidraget till UNICEF till 351 000 000 SEK. Det totala initiala bidrag som föreslås för 2018 uppgår till 243 200 000 SEK och är uppdelat på de följande kategorierna:
A. Landspecifikt stöd: Den förslagna landfördelningen för 2018 (identifierade under allokeringsprocessen) omfattar totalt SEK 202 000 000 med stöd till UNICEFs humanitära arbete inom sektorerna hälsa, nutrition, utbildning, barnskyddsfrågor, könsrelaterat våld och vatten och sanitet:
O-öronmärkt stöd: 1. Syrien krisen 25 000 000 SEK 2. Somaliakrisen 14 000 000 SEK 3. Demokratiska Folk Republiken Korea 8 000 000 SEK 4. Jemen 30 000 000 SEK 5. Niger 6 000 000 SEK 6. Nigeria 25 000 000 SEK 7. Irak 13 000 000 SEK 8. Etiopien 25 000 000 SEK 9. Mali 7 000 000 SEK 10. Tchad 4 000 000 SEK 11. Sudan 10 000 000 SEK 12. Sydsudan 14 000 000 SEK
Öronmärkt stöd: 1. Burundi 6 000 000 SEK (Skydd av barn och WASH) 2. CAR 5 000 000 SEK (Rapid Response Mechanism/RRM) 3. DRK 10 000 000 SEK (Rapid Response to Movements of Population (RRMP)
B. Snabb responsmekanism i form av oallokerade medel: Det föreslås även ett stöd om 38 000 000 SEK för 2018 och 2 000 000 SEK per år för 2019, 2020 och 2021 som UNICEF kan rekvirera och använda efter godkännande från Sida, för nya eller förvärrade humanitära kriser.
C. Slutligen föreslås metod/tematiskt stöd till projekt som bidrar till att stärka den humanitära responsen, specifikt ökad deltagande av den drabbade befolkningen (AAP) i CAR men 3 200 000 SEK för 2018 och 2 300 000 SEK för 2019.
Det föreslås at Sida ska ingå två avtal med UNICEF i syfte att särskilja det stöd som går till de humanitära appellerna respektive metodstöd. Detta är i enlighet med önskemål från UNICEF i syfte att förenkla deras hantering.
Sidas stöd till UNICEF är baserat på FNs samordnade humanitära responsplaner (HRP) samt UNICEFs ’Humanitarian Action for Children' (HAC). Bidraget kommer att allokeras till UNICEF på landnivå med både öronmärkt eller o-öronmärkt stöd. Sida väljer att öronmärkta stödet till vissa kriser för att säkerställa att de sektorer eller komponenter med störst humanitära behoven enligt behovsanalysen adresseras. Inom det humanitära systemet är UNICEF en central aktör med ett särskilt mandat som riktar sig till barn och mödrar i konfliktsituationer eller naturkatastrofer. Genom stödet kommer organisationen därmed ge livräddande och livsuppehållande stöd till de mest utsatta grupperna med fokus på barn och kvinnor i humanitära situationer. Stödet kommer att inkludera nya akuta humanitära situationer, pågående samt eskalerande kriser.
Sidas stöd till UNICEF kommer förutom att bidra med humanitär finansiering för att bistå utsatta grupper i humanitära kriser även att bidra till samordnad och effektiv respons i de utvalda länderna. UNICEF ansvarar för att leda och samordna de globala klustren för nutrition, utbildning, vatten och sanitet samt har ansvar för skydd av barn.
UNICEF har framfört att tidig utbetalning av årliga bidrag för humanitära insatser är en förutsättning för att organisationen ska kunna ingå förpliktelser i form av anställning av personal och kunna påbörja den upphandling av de varor och tjänster som behövs för den humanitära responsen. UNICEF har en väl utvecklad logistik med lager i regionala depåer och har en roll i det humanitära systemet att även förse andra implementerande partners med varor. Humanitära kriser är till sin karaktär snabbt skiftande både geografiskt och i intensitet, UNICEF måste därför vara beredda att kunna flytta såväl personal som förnödenheter.
Sida delar UNICEFs bedömning att det föreligger ett behov av att kunna planera och förbereda insatser utan onödig fördröjning och bedömer därför att samtliga medel för projektet ska utbetalas ut omgående för att möjliggöra planering och uppstart av projektet till 1 januari 2018. Ett avsteg från Sidas vanliga rutiner om uppdelade betalningar bedöms motiverat.
Bedömningspromemorian har skrivits på engelska med anledning av att engelskspråkig personal i fält är delaktig i beredning och uppföljning av insatsen, i enlighet med Generaldirektörens beslut om Sidas språkvalsmatris med tillämpningsanvisningar från den 1 mars 2013.

To save lives and alleviate suffering for children in who's lives have been affected due to conflict and natural disasters worldwide; mainly in the sectors of nutrition, health, water and sanitation and hygiene, as well as in emergency education, child protection and gender-based violence (GBV).

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: Sida has received the annual report for 2019 (30 June 2020) and we are happy to note that in the more than 20 different contexts the following examples of achievements are reported: In Cameroon UNICEF humanitarian assistance primarily focused on refugees who fled the armed conflict in Central African Republic (CAR) and their host communities, to IDPs caused by the ongoing crisis in the North West and South West of Cameroon and to persons displaced by Boko Haram attacks in Far North region inlcuding refugees and outsed restablished camps. - Nationally, 79 311 (target 65 064) children aged 6-59 months with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) were admitted for treatment where 137 additional primary health facilities were possible to include in this emergency response (compared to a target figure of 702). - Nationally, UNICEF implementing partners reached 54 240 target families/households with at least 1 long-lasting insecticidal nets or 83% of the target figure of 62 739 familieis/households. - 152 947 children (6 months to 15 years) were vaccinated against measles (target 266 492). - Funding shortfalls impacted the planned WASH results with only 22 000 people supported with sustainable access to safe drinking water against a taret of 110 000 while 23 456 people were assisted with access to adequate basic sanitation agianst a target of 75 000 pople. The WASH sector received an overall funding level of only 8% against the requirement. - Also in the education sector, low funding led to poor emergency education results in 2019. Over 5 900 girls and boys (3-17 years) receive learning materials, well below the target of 217 989. - With a bit more appropriate funding for child protection, 141 555 children were reached with psycho-social support including child friendly spaces, against a goal of 289 789. In Syria, despite the complex environment UNICEF worked to deliver humanitarian assistance within the Whole of Syria (WoS) approach. UNICEF focused on multi-sectoral response addressing Health, Nutrition, WASH, Education and Protection needs and Social Protection. UNICEF has been progressively strengthening its focus on the longer term by scaling-up resilience building interventions and will continue to move in this direction: - UNICEF supported over 2 million women and children to receive primary health care consultations across Syria. This was 91% of target and was due to the constrained access in some areas of Idlib. - The expansion of vaccination services ensured that over 500 000 children under-1 received diphteria-tetanus-pertussis vaccination and over 3 million children were immunized against polio. - Access to services by vulnerable groups such as women and children were enhanced by the increasing use of mobile teams with female health workers in some of the hard to reach communities and IDP camps. - UNICEF supported the screening of about 1.8 million children under-5 and pregnant and lactating women for acute malnutrition. Of the total children screened, 11 498 were found to be affected by SAM and received life-saving treatment. - Emergency WASH interventions reached over 1 million people through the distribution of non-food items (NFIs) including family hygiene kits, soap and aqua tabs and installation of water tanks in camps, host communities and IDP shelters across the country. - To strengthen girls' and boys' coping mechanisms and resilience, UNICEF provided psychosocial support services to about 393 500 children (50% girls) through fixed and mobile modalities. The target was overachieved as services were provided to address needs arising from new displacements and expansion in Deir-ez-Zor, Al Hasakeh and Aleppo. In Nigeria, UNICEF delivered an integrated package of interventions to conflict-affected populations in the northeast and handed over a greater share of service delivery to partners whose capacity in the region is increasing: - UNICEF reached 249 776 people in Borno state with temporary access to safe water, primarily through water trucking in hard-to-reach areas and areas where geological issues do not allow for the construction of new water facilities. - In collaboration with the Borno and Adamawa states, UNICEF sustained access to safe water to 771 428 people in Borno and 1.7 million people in Adamawa. - UNICEF supported the release of 461 children (57 girls and 404 boys) in line with the action plan signed with relevant partners. UNICEF is also providing reintegration services to all released children. - 358 962 children received psychosocial support services (reached 100% of target) and worked to reunify 275 unaccompanied and separated children with their familieis, while 752 children benefitted from alternative care placement. - Birth registration results exceeded planned targets, for children under-5 there were 94% births registered (versus a target of 54%), while children under-1 were registered 99% (target 72%). - A number of 3 969 664 conflict-affected people were reached with integrated primary health care services (approximately half of which were under-5). This included curative care, preventive services and women supported with safe deliveries and post-natal care. - A number of 138 772 children (target 158 488) aged 6-59 months with SAM were admitted to therapeutic care for specified period where 95% recovered.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

New/additional funds to address COVID-19 Each year Sida undertakes a humanitarian allocation process (Humanitarian Crises Analysis/HCA) in which all humanitarian crises are analysed, and where the partners most relevant to respond to the identified needs are selected. Based on the overall analysis of UNICEF as a key partner, it is suggested to enter a new agreement the organization and provide support during the period 2018-2021, which is in line with the new UNICEF Strategic Plan 2018-2021. UNICEF will continue to receive an unearmarked allocation (38 000 000 SEK) for ongoing, revised or new operations in accordance with the objectives of the Humanitarian programmes (UN Appeals and UNICEF Humanitarian Action for Children/HAC). For 2018, an additional amount of 202 000 000 SEK will be made available for specific humanitarian programmes in 15 crises which will be presented below. Furthermore, support will be provided to technical projects and programmes that may be outside the UNICEF HAC Appeals but that contribute to the strengthening and improving activities and cross cutting issues related to humanitarian appeals.
An amount of SEK 3 200 000 for 2018 and SEK 2 300 000 for 2019 will also be utilized for the inter-agency collective service for community engagement and accountability project proposal which is hosted by UNICEF on the behalf of the Communication with Communities Working Group (CwCWG). The funds will be directed for the Central African Republic (CAR) context. This project aims to improve the humanitarian response in CAR by strengthening the accountability to the affected population (AAP).

B. Snabb responsmekanism i form av oallokerade medel: Det föreslås även ett stöd om 38 000 000 SEK för 2018 och 2 000 000 SEK per år för 2019, 2020 och 2021 som UNICEF kan rekvirera och använda efter godkännande från Sida, för nya eller förvärrade humanitära kriser.
C. Slutligen föreslås metod/tematiskt stöd till projekt som bidrar till att stärka den humanitära responsen, specifikt ökad deltagande av den drabbade befolkningen (AAP) i CAR men 3 200 000 SEK för 2018 och 2 300 000 SEK för 2019.
Det föreslås at Sida ska ingå två avtal med UNICEF i syfte att särskilja det stöd som går till de humanitära appellerna respektive metodstöd. Detta är i enlighet med önskemål från UNICEF i syfte att förenkla deras hantering.
Sidas stöd till UNICEF är baserat på FNs samordnade humanitära responsplaner (HRP) samt UNICEFs ’Humanitarian Action for Children' (HAC). Bidraget kommer att allokeras till UNICEF på landnivå med både öronmärkt eller o-öronmärkt stöd. Sida väljer att öronmärkta stödet till vissa kriser för att säkerställa att de sektorer eller komponenter med störst humanitära behoven enligt behovsanalysen adresseras. Inom det humanitära systemet är UNICEF en central aktör med ett särskilt mandat som riktar sig till barn och mödrar i konfliktsituationer eller naturkatastrofer. Genom stödet kommer organisationen därmed ge livräddande och livsuppehållande stöd till de mest utsatta grupperna med fokus på barn och kvinnor i humanitära situationer. Stödet kommer att inkludera nya akuta humanitära situationer, pågående samt eskalerande kriser.
Sidas stöd till UNICEF kommer förutom att bidra med humanitär finansiering för att bistå utsatta grupper i humanitära kriser även att bidra till samordnad och effektiv respons i de utvalda länderna. UNICEF ansvarar för att leda och samordna de globala klustren för nutrition, utbildning, vatten och sanitet samt har ansvar för skydd av barn.
UNICEF har framfört att tidig utbetalning av årliga bidrag för humanitära insatser är en förutsättning för att organisationen ska kunna ingå förpliktelser i form av anställning av personal och kunna påbörja den upphandling av de varor och tjänster som behövs för den humanitära responsen. UNICEF har en väl utvecklad logistik med lager i regionala depåer och har en roll i det humanitära systemet att även förse andra implementerande partners med varor. Humanitära kriser är till sin karaktär snabbt skiftande både geografiskt och i intensitet, UNICEF måste därför vara beredda att kunna flytta såväl personal som förnödenheter.
Sida delar UNICEFs bedömning att det föreligger ett behov av att kunna planera och förbereda insatser utan onödig fördröjning och bedömer därför att samtliga medel för projektet ska utbetalas ut omgående för att möjliggöra planering och uppstart av projektet till 1 januari 2018. Ett avsteg från Sidas vanliga rutiner om uppdelade betalningar bedöms motiverat.
Bedömningspromemorian har skrivits på engelska med anledning av att engelskspråkig personal i fält är delaktig i beredning och uppföljning av insatsen, i enlighet med Generaldirektörens beslut om Sidas språkvalsmatris med tillämpningsanvisningar från den 1 mars 2013.

To save lives and alleviate suffering for children in who's lives have been affected due to conflict and natural disasters worldwide; mainly in the sectors of nutrition, health, water and sanitation and hygiene, as well as in emergency education, child protection and gender-based violence (GBV).

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: Sida has received the annual report for 2019 (30 June 2020) and we are happy to note that in the more than 20 different contexts the following examples of achievements are reported: In Cameroon UNICEF humanitarian assistance primarily focused on refugees who fled the armed conflict in Central African Republic (CAR) and their host communities, to IDPs caused by the ongoing crisis in the North West and South West of Cameroon and to persons displaced by Boko Haram attacks in Far North region inlcuding refugees and outsed restablished camps. - Nationally, 79 311 (target 65 064) children aged 6-59 months with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) were admitted for treatment where 137 additional primary health facilities were possible to include in this emergency response (compared to a target figure of 702). - Nationally, UNICEF implementing partners reached 54 240 target families/households with at least 1 long-lasting insecticidal nets or 83% of the target figure of 62 739 familieis/households. - 152 947 children (6 months to 15 years) were vaccinated against measles (target 266 492). - Funding shortfalls impacted the planned WASH results with only 22 000 people supported with sustainable access to safe drinking water against a taret of 110 000 while 23 456 people were assisted with access to adequate basic sanitation agianst a target of 75 000 pople. The WASH sector received an overall funding level of only 8% against the requirement. - Also in the education sector, low funding led to poor emergency education results in 2019. Over 5 900 girls and boys (3-17 years) receive learning materials, well below the target of 217 989. - With a bit more appropriate funding for child protection, 141 555 children were reached with psycho-social support including child friendly spaces, against a goal of 289 789. In Syria, despite the complex environment UNICEF worked to deliver humanitarian assistance within the Whole of Syria (WoS) approach. UNICEF focused on multi-sectoral response addressing Health, Nutrition, WASH, Education and Protection needs and Social Protection. UNICEF has been progressively strengthening its focus on the longer term by scaling-up resilience building interventions and will continue to move in this direction: - UNICEF supported over 2 million women and children to receive primary health care consultations across Syria. This was 91% of target and was due to the constrained access in some areas of Idlib. - The expansion of vaccination services ensured that over 500 000 children under-1 received diphteria-tetanus-pertussis vaccination and over 3 million children were immunized against polio. - Access to services by vulnerable groups such as women and children were enhanced by the increasing use of mobile teams with female health workers in some of the hard to reach communities and IDP camps. - UNICEF supported the screening of about 1.8 million children under-5 and pregnant and lactating women for acute malnutrition. Of the total children screened, 11 498 were found to be affected by SAM and received life-saving treatment. - Emergency WASH interventions reached over 1 million people through the distribution of non-food items (NFIs) including family hygiene kits, soap and aqua tabs and installation of water tanks in camps, host communities and IDP shelters across the country. - To strengthen girls' and boys' coping mechanisms and resilience, UNICEF provided psychosocial support services to about 393 500 children (50% girls) through fixed and mobile modalities. The target was overachieved as services were provided to address needs arising from new displacements and expansion in Deir-ez-Zor, Al Hasakeh and Aleppo. In Nigeria, UNICEF delivered an integrated package of interventions to conflict-affected populations in the northeast and handed over a greater share of service delivery to partners whose capacity in the region is increasing: - UNICEF reached 249 776 people in Borno state with temporary access to safe water, primarily through water trucking in hard-to-reach areas and areas where geological issues do not allow for the construction of new water facilities. - In collaboration with the Borno and Adamawa states, UNICEF sustained access to safe water to 771 428 people in Borno and 1.7 million people in Adamawa. - UNICEF supported the release of 461 children (57 girls and 404 boys) in line with the action plan signed with relevant partners. UNICEF is also providing reintegration services to all released children. - 358 962 children received psychosocial support services (reached 100% of target) and worked to reunify 275 unaccompanied and separated children with their familieis, while 752 children benefitted from alternative care placement. - Birth registration results exceeded planned targets, for children under-5 there were 94% births registered (versus a target of 54%), while children under-1 were registered 99% (target 72%). - A number of 3 969 664 conflict-affected people were reached with integrated primary health care services (approximately half of which were under-5). This included curative care, preventive services and women supported with safe deliveries and post-natal care. - A number of 138 772 children (target 158 488) aged 6-59 months with SAM were admitted to therapeutic care for specified period where 95% recovered.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

New/additional funds to address COVID-19 Each year Sida undertakes a humanitarian allocation process (Humanitarian Crises Analysis/HCA) in which all humanitarian crises are analysed, and where the partners most relevant to respond to the identified needs are selected. Based on the overall analysis of UNICEF as a key partner, it is suggested to enter a new agreement the organization and provide support during the period 2018-2021, which is in line with the new UNICEF Strategic Plan 2018-2021. UNICEF will continue to receive an unearmarked allocation (38 000 000 SEK) for ongoing, revised or new operations in accordance with the objectives of the Humanitarian programmes (UN Appeals and UNICEF Humanitarian Action for Children/HAC). For 2018, an additional amount of 202 000 000 SEK will be made available for specific humanitarian programmes in 15 crises which will be presented below. Furthermore, support will be provided to technical projects and programmes that may be outside the UNICEF HAC Appeals but that contribute to the strengthening and improving activities and cross cutting issues related to humanitarian appeals.
An amount of SEK 3 200 000 for 2018 and SEK 2 300 000 for 2019 will also be utilized for the inter-agency collective service for community engagement and accountability project proposal which is hosted by UNICEF on the behalf of the Communication with Communities Working Group (CwCWG). The funds will be directed for the Central African Republic (CAR) context. This project aims to improve the humanitarian response in CAR by strengthening the accountability to the affected population (AAP).

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 Den globala trenden med ökade humanitära behov fortsätter under 2018 och i början på året beräknas 90,9 miljoner människor i 26 länder vara i behov av humanitärt stöd och FN:s appeller uppgår till 22,5 miljarder dollar.
Sida genomför årligen en humanitär allokeringsprocess då de omkring 15 stora pågående humanitära kriserna analyseras utifrån de humanitära behoven och där de mest relevanta av strategiska partnerorganisationer identifieras. Det aktuella stödet till UNICEF i 15 länder/kriser baseras på Sidas humanitära allokering, som färdigställdes under slutet av 2017. Stödet till UNICEF bedöms relevant för att uppnå målen i Strategi för Sveriges humanitära bistånd genom Sida 2017-2020.
Under 2017 uppgick det totala utbetalda Sida humanitära bidraget till UNICEF till 351 000 000 SEK. Det totala initiala bidrag som föreslås för 2018 uppgår till 243 200 000 SEK och är uppdelat på de följande kategorierna:
A. Landspecifikt stöd: Den förslagna landfördelningen för 2018 (identifierade under allokeringsprocessen) omfattar totalt SEK 202 000 000 med stöd till UNICEFs humanitära arbete inom sektorerna hälsa, nutrition, utbildning, barnskyddsfrågor, könsrelaterat våld och vatten och sanitet:
O-öronmärkt stöd: 1. Syrien krisen 25 000 000 SEK 2. Somaliakrisen 14 000 000 SEK 3. Demokratiska Folk Republiken Korea 8 000 000 SEK 4. Jemen 30 000 000 SEK 5. Niger 6 000 000 SEK 6. Nigeria 25 000 000 SEK 7. Irak 13 000 000 SEK 8. Etiopien 25 000 000 SEK 9. Mali 7 000 000 SEK 10. Tchad 4 000 000 SEK 11. Sudan 10 000 000 SEK 12. Sydsudan 14 000 000 SEK
Öronmärkt stöd: 1. Burundi 6 000 000 SEK (Skydd av barn och WASH) 2. CAR 5 000 000 SEK (Rapid Response Mechanism/RRM) 3. DRK 10 000 000 SEK (Rapid Response to Movements of Population (RRMP)
B. Snabb responsmekanism i form av oallokerade medel: Det föreslås även ett stöd om 38 000 000 SEK för 2018 och 2 000 000 SEK per år för 2019, 2020 och 2021 som UNICEF kan rekvirera och använda efter godkännande från Sida, för nya eller förvärrade humanitära kriser.
C. Slutligen föreslås metod/tematiskt stöd till projekt som bidrar till att stärka den humanitära responsen, specifikt ökad deltagande av den drabbade befolkningen (AAP) i CAR men 3 200 000 SEK för 2018 och 2 300 000 SEK för 2019.
Det föreslås at Sida ska ingå två avtal med UNICEF i syfte att särskilja det stöd som går till de humanitära appellerna respektive metodstöd. Detta är i enlighet med önskemål från UNICEF i syfte att förenkla deras hantering.
Sidas stöd till UNICEF är baserat på FNs samordnade humanitära responsplaner (HRP) samt UNICEFs ’Humanitarian Action for Children' (HAC). Bidraget kommer att allokeras till UNICEF på landnivå med både öronmärkt eller o-öronmärkt stöd. Sida väljer att öronmärkta stödet till vissa kriser för att säkerställa att de sektorer eller komponenter med störst humanitära behoven enligt behovsanalysen adresseras. Inom det humanitära systemet är UNICEF en central aktör med ett särskilt mandat som riktar sig till barn och mödrar i konfliktsituationer eller naturkatastrofer. Genom stödet kommer organisationen därmed ge livräddande och livsuppehållande stöd till de mest utsatta grupperna med fokus på barn och kvinnor i humanitära situationer. Stödet kommer att inkludera nya akuta humanitära situationer, pågående samt eskalerande kriser.
Sidas stöd till UNICEF kommer förutom att bidra med humanitär finansiering för att bistå utsatta grupper i humanitära kriser även att bidra till samordnad och effektiv respons i de utvalda länderna. UNICEF ansvarar för att leda och samordna de globala klustren för nutrition, utbildning, vatten och sanitet samt har ansvar för skydd av barn.
UNICEF har framfört att tidig utbetalning av årliga bidrag för humanitära insatser är en förutsättning för att organisationen ska kunna ingå förpliktelser i form av anställning av personal och kunna påbörja den upphandling av de varor och tjänster som behövs för den humanitära responsen. UNICEF har en väl utvecklad logistik med lager i regionala depåer och har en roll i det humanitära systemet att även förse andra implementerande partners med varor. Humanitära kriser är till sin karaktär snabbt skiftande både geografiskt och i intensitet, UNICEF måste därför vara beredda att kunna flytta såväl personal som förnödenheter.
Sida delar UNICEFs bedömning att det föreligger ett behov av att kunna planera och förbereda insatser utan onödig fördröjning och bedömer därför att samtliga medel för projektet ska utbetalas ut omgående för att möjliggöra planering och uppstart av projektet till 1 januari 2018. Ett avsteg från Sidas vanliga rutiner om uppdelade betalningar bedöms motiverat.
Bedömningspromemorian har skrivits på engelska med anledning av att engelskspråkig personal i fält är delaktig i beredning och uppföljning av insatsen, i enlighet med Generaldirektörens beslut om Sidas språkvalsmatris med tillämpningsanvisningar från den 1 mars 2013.

description.narrative: Sida has received the annual report for 2019 (30 June 2020) and we are happy to note that in the more than 20 different contexts the following examples of achievements are reported: In Cameroon UNICEF humanitarian assistance primarily focused on refugees who fled the armed conflict in Central African Republic (CAR) and their host communities, to IDPs caused by the ongoing crisis in the North West and South West of Cameroon and to persons displaced by Boko Haram attacks in Far North region inlcuding refugees and outsed restablished camps. - Nationally, 79 311 (target 65 064) children aged 6-59 months with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) were admitted for treatment where 137 additional primary health facilities were possible to include in this emergency response (compared to a target figure of 702). - Nationally, UNICEF implementing partners reached 54 240 target families/households with at least 1 long-lasting insecticidal nets or 83% of the target figure of 62 739 familieis/households. - 152 947 children (6 months to 15 years) were vaccinated against measles (target 266 492). - Funding shortfalls impacted the planned WASH results with only 22 000 people supported with sustainable access to safe drinking water against a taret of 110 000 while 23 456 people were assisted with access to adequate basic sanitation agianst a target of 75 000 pople. The WASH sector received an overall funding level of only 8% against the requirement. - Also in the education sector, low funding led to poor emergency education results in 2019. Over 5 900 girls and boys (3-17 years) receive learning materials, well below the target of 217 989. - With a bit more appropriate funding for child protection, 141 555 children were reached with psycho-social support including child friendly spaces, against a goal of 289 789. In Syria, despite the complex environment UNICEF worked to deliver humanitarian assistance within the Whole of Syria (WoS) approach. UNICEF focused on multi-sectoral response addressing Health, Nutrition, WASH, Education and Protection needs and Social Protection. UNICEF has been progressively strengthening its focus on the longer term by scaling-up resilience building interventions and will continue to move in this direction: - UNICEF supported over 2 million women and children to receive primary health care consultations across Syria. This was 91% of target and was due to the constrained access in some areas of Idlib. - The expansion of vaccination services ensured that over 500 000 children under-1 received diphteria-tetanus-pertussis vaccination and over 3 million children were immunized against polio. - Access to services by vulnerable groups such as women and children were enhanced by the increasing use of mobile teams with female health workers in some of the hard to reach communities and IDP camps. - UNICEF supported the screening of about 1.8 million children under-5 and pregnant and lactating women for acute malnutrition. Of the total children screened, 11 498 were found to be affected by SAM and received life-saving treatment. - Emergency WASH interventions reached over 1 million people through the distribution of non-food items (NFIs) including family hygiene kits, soap and aqua tabs and installation of water tanks in camps, host communities and IDP shelters across the country. - To strengthen girls' and boys' coping mechanisms and resilience, UNICEF provided psychosocial support services to about 393 500 children (50% girls) through fixed and mobile modalities. The target was overachieved as services were provided to address needs arising from new displacements and expansion in Deir-ez-Zor, Al Hasakeh and Aleppo. In Nigeria, UNICEF delivered an integrated package of interventions to conflict-affected populations in the northeast and handed over a greater share of service delivery to partners whose capacity in the region is increasing: - UNICEF reached 249 776 people in Borno state with temporary access to safe water, primarily through water trucking in hard-to-reach areas and areas where geological issues do not allow for the construction of new water facilities. - In collaboration with the Borno and Adamawa states, UNICEF sustained access to safe water to 771 428 people in Borno and 1.7 million people in Adamawa. - UNICEF supported the release of 461 children (57 girls and 404 boys) in line with the action plan signed with relevant partners. UNICEF is also providing reintegration services to all released children. - 358 962 children received psychosocial support services (reached 100% of target) and worked to reunify 275 unaccompanied and separated children with their familieis, while 752 children benefitted from alternative care placement. - Birth registration results exceeded planned targets, for children under-5 there were 94% births registered (versus a target of 54%), while children under-1 were registered 99% (target 72%). - A number of 3 969 664 conflict-affected people were reached with integrated primary health care services (approximately half of which were under-5). This included curative care, preventive services and women supported with safe deliveries and post-natal care. - A number of 138 772 children (target 158 488) aged 6-59 months with SAM were admitted to therapeutic care for specified period where 95% recovered.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 UNDP Funding Facility for Stabilization(FFS) avser att stödja den irakiska regeringens stabiliserings- och återuppbyggnadsbehov i de återtagna områdena, tidigare under IS kontroll, för att bidra till ett säkert och hållbart återvändande av internflyktingar till dessa områden (fokus fyra governorat; Anbar, Salah al-Din, Diyala, Nineweh, som inkluderar östra och västra Mosul).
Faciliteten etablerades av UNDP i dialog med den irakiska regeringen 2015, med stöd från givarsamhället, på grund av den pågående militära konflikten med IS, med omfattande strömmar av internflyktingar och humanitär kris som följd i stora delar av Irak.
Faciliteten är den enda i sitt slag i Irak som verkar så brett inom området för stabilisering och tidig återuppbyggnad och kompletterar det internationella humanitära stödet som annars är det mest omfattande i Irak. Sverige var ett av de drivande länderna för fondfacilitetens tillkomst, och stöd till UNDP har getts av Sverige via UD sedan 2015. Idag samlar fondfaciliteten 24 givarländer, där Sverige fortfarande är en av de största givarna.
Faciliteten består av två kanaler för stöd, Funding Facilitiy for Immediate Stabilization (FFIS) och fr o m 2016 också Funding Facility for Expanding Stabilization (FFES). Den första kanalen fokuserar på stöd till reparation av lätt infrastruktur som kan bidra till att få igång basala samhällstjänster inom sektorer som bl a vatten, el, avlopp, hälsa och utbildning samt kapacitetsstärkande stöd till lokala myndigheter. Det kompletteras med olika komponenter av försörjningsstöd (t ex cash-for work schemes) till utsatta grupper, som återvändande internflyktingar och kvinnoledda hushåll, samt finansiella bidrag till privata näringsidkare som kan bidra till att få igång det lokala näringslivet samt stöd till social sammanhållning (fredsbyggande mellan olika grupper). Programmet bidrar till att bygga resiliens i dessa utsatta lokalsamhällen.
Därutöver kompletteras faciliteten med en andra kanal, FFES, för att möta behovet av stöd till återuppbyggnad av mer omfattande infrastruktur, som t ex rehabilitering av sjukhusbyggnader, universitet, samt rehabilitering av objekt som broar och vägar som i sin tur bidrar till att upprätta stabiliseringskorridorer mellan återtagna områden och städer.
Den preliminära budgeten för hela faciliteten fram till 2023 är 1 880 000 000 USD.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The Funding Facility for Stabilization (FFS) consists of two channels of support, the original Funding Facility for Immediate Stabilisation (FFIS) and the more recently established channel Funding Facility for Expanded Stabilisation (FFES).
The FFS aim at immediate stabilisation and recovery measures in the liberated areas of IS control, in order for sustainable return of internally displaced persons (IDP) back to these areas (focus four governorat; Anbar, Salah al-Din, Diyala, Nineweh including east and west Mosul).

The Government of Iraq is supported to address the immediate stabilisation and recovery needs in geographical areas retaken from IS in Anbar, Ninewa, Salah-Din, Kirkuk and Diyala which allows for the sustainable return of internally displaced persons (IDPs). FFS is organised in windows that support four types of activities: 1) Public works and light infrastructure rehabilitation with focus on education, electricity, health, housing, roads and bridges, sewage and water; 2) Livelihood assistance including employment; 3) Capacity support including to municipalities; and 4) Peaceful communities through Social cohesion. The intended outcome of the intervention is that people in Iraq, civil society and communities, particularly women, have improved capacity to lead, participate in and contribute to the design and delivery of equitable and responsive services, especially for the most vulnerable populations. The ouputs of the project are: Output 1: Iraqi Government in newly liberated areas is supported to address immediate challenges for return of internally displaced persons. 1.1 Carry out local assessments to identify immediate stabilization needs 1.2 Rehabilitate priority light infrastructure in newly liberated areas 1.3 Support immediate income generation opportunities (Window 2) 1.4. Capacity development of Government authorities to facilitate stabilization (Window 3) 1.5 Design and implement initiatives to promote social cohesion Output 2 High impact medium-sized infrastructure projects are rehabilitated to sustain stabilization gains (FFES) 2.1 Rehabilitation of priority, medium-size infrastructure projects Output 3: Exit Strategy is drafted in consultation with the Government of Iraq, for the liberated governorates. 3.1 Exit Strategy for post-FFS stabilization and development work in the liberated governorates.

tag.narrative: 1.5 - By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters.

1.5 - Till 2030 bygga upp motståndskraften hos de fattiga och människor i utsatta situationer och minska deras utsatthet och sårbarhet för extrema klimatrelaterade händelser och andra ekonomiska, sociala och miljömässiga chocker och katastrofer.
13.1 - Strengthen resilience and adaptive capacity to climate-related hazards and natural disasters in all countries.
13.1 - Stärka motståndskraften mot och förmågan till anpassning till klimatrelaterade faror och naturkatastrofer i alla länder.
16.6 - Bygga upp effektiva och transparenta institutioner med ansvarsutkrävande på alla nivåer.
16.6 - Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.
16.7 - Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.
16.7 - Säkerställa ett lyhört, inkluderande, deltagandebaserat och representativt beslutsfattande på alla nivåer.
3.3 - By 2030, end the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases.
3.3 - Senast 2030 utrota epidemierna av aids, tuberkulos, malaria och försummade tropiska sjukdomar samt bekämpa hepatit, vattenburna sjukdomar och andra smittsamma sjukdomar.
5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.

description.narrative: By the end of 2019, 2 320 projects was completed and 8 510 829 Iraqis ( 4 250 462 women) had benefited from stabilization activities. Thanks in part to the enabling environment created by FFS supported activities about 4, 5 million Iraqis are estimated by IOM to have returned to their area of origin (end of 2019). The commitment of the the GoI to stabilisation was demonstrated in 2019 by the signing of a financing agreement between UNDP and GoI whereby the GoI will contribute USD 33 million to UNDP for stabilization activities. Examples on results:- FFS continued rehabilitating educational facilities, including kindergartens, primary and secondary schools, technical institutes and university buildings.- Work in health sector saw progress both in large scale hospital rehabilitation projects as well as the rehabilitation of community Primary Healthcare Centres.- In West Mosul, significant progress was made in the housing sector, with a total of 4 704 housing units rehabilitating.- In the livelihoods sector, FFS created job opportunities for more than 11000 workers through cash for work. Grant to women-headed households were also distributed with 1000 grants given to women in West Mosul and 3000 grants distributed in Ramani.- Three new bridges had been rehabilitated in East Mosul.- To promote stability, resolve local conflicts and facilitate the return of IDPs, FFS has, in collaboration with GoI and local authorities, supported two community reconciliation initiatives in Salah al Din and Anbar.- In Ninewa, 116 water projects have been completed, including the rehabilitation of the largest single Water Treatment Plant in East Mosul that serves a population of approximately 700 000 in 30 neighbourhoods. The results will be updated in a new Conclusion of Performance when the Annual report for 2020 has been received.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Education Cannot Wait (ECW) är en ny global fond dedikerad år utbildning i konflikt- och krissituationer. ECWs övergripande mål är att till 2021 nå ut till 8 miljoner flickor, pojkar och ungdomar, bland annat från marginaliserade grupper, som lever i krissituationer för att förbättra deras möjligheter att lära och ta till sig kunskap och därmed öka deras välbefinnande och anställningsbarhet. Detta genom att 1) inspirera till ökat politiskt engagemang så att utbildning betraktas av både regeringar och finansiärer som högt prioriterat i krissituationer, 2) generera ökad och additionell finansiering för utbildning i kris- och konfliktsituationer, 3) bidra till ökad gemensam planering och genomförande av utbildningsinsatser i kris- och konfliktsituationer, 4) stärka lokal och global kapacitet, och 5) förbättra ansvarsskyldigheten genom att utveckla och dela kunskap och bidra till ökad insamling och analys av data. Sida bidrar med 180 000 000 SEK som är icke-öronmärkt till ECWs globala fond, samt med 90 000 000 SEK för att finansiera implementeringen av ECWs fleråriga utbildningsprogram i Afghanistan som planeras nå 500 000 barn årligen med speciellt fokus på flickor, intern- och återvändande flyktingar.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Support to Education Cannot Wait (ECW), a new global fund dedicated to transform the delivery of education in emergencies. The overarching goal of ECW is to by 2021 be reaching 8 million crisis-affected girls, boys and youth, including from marginalized groups, improving their learning outcomes and enhancing their socio-emotional wellbeing and employability. It will do so by 1) increase political support to education in crises; 2) increase financing for education in crises; 3) improve joint planning and responses; 4) strengthen local and global capacity; and 5) improve accountability. Sida is contributing with SEK 180 000 000 in un-earmarked global support to ECW’s pooled fund, and with SEK 90 000 000 to the ECW facilitated multiyear programme in Afghanistan which will target 500 000 children annually focusing on girls, internally displaced people and returnee refugee communities.

i. Overarching Goal: By 2021, ECW supported interventions will be reaching 8 million crisis-affected girls, boys and youth, including from marginalized groups, improving their learning outcomes and enhancing their socio-emotional wellbeing and employability. ii. Strategic objectives: 1. Increase political support to education in crises (Increase high-level attention with an aim towards greater equity of response, with an emphasis on the most vulnerable and reaching neglected crises) 2. Increase financing for education in crises (Raise significant additional money to support interventions that improve access, quality, continuity, protection, equity and gender equality) 3. Improve joint planning and responses (Unite humanitarian and development efforts in support of national preparedness and responses to education crises through facilitating the development of joint programmes) 4. Strengthen local and global capacity (Strengthen individual and institutional capacity of those leading education efforts in crises and improve delivery systems) 5. Improve accountability (Develop and share knowledge with a focus on increasing awareness of need and evidence for effective interventions) iii. The ECW Facilitated Multi-Year Programme, Afghanistan: The programme aims to achieve its goals through mutually supportive five key outcomes and results: Outcome 1: Access to education for emergency-affected girls and boys is increased. Outcome 2: Conducive, child-friendly and inclusive teaching and learning environment enabled for emergency affected girls and boys. Outcome 3: Increased continuity of education for emergency-affected girls and boys. Outcome 4: Quality of learning for emergency-affected girls and boys is improved. Outcome 5: Safe and protective learning environment for emergency-affected girls and boys, especially the most marginalized, are established and strengthened.

tag.narrative: 4.1 - By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.
4.1 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla flickor och pojkar fullbordar avgiftsfri och likvärdig grundskole- och gymnasieutbildning av god kvalitet som leder till relevanta och ändamålsenliga kunskaper.
4.2 - By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys have access to quality early childhood development, care and pre-primary education so that they are ready for primary education.
4.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla flickor och pojkar har tillgång till förskola av god kvalitet som ger omvårdnad och förbereder dem för att börja grundskolan.
4.6 - By 2030, ensure that all youth and a substantial proportion of adults, both men and women, achieve literacy and numeracy.
4.6 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla ungdomar och en väsentlig andel av alla vuxna – både män och kvinnor – lär sig läsa, skriva och räkna.

title.narrative: Agreement with UNICEF for Education Cannot Wait 2018-2020
Beslut om insats Education Cannot Wait 2018-2020

description.narrative: Up until March 2020, the following results have been achieved in Afghanistan: • 118,212 children in nine (9) crises affected provinces have access to education (69,210 girls and 49,002 boys); • 3,478 Community-Based Education (CBE) learning spaces have been established. CBE is an outreach education model for underserved areas that is part of the formal education system in Afghanistan; • 3,620 teachers out of which 1,658 females and 1,962 males have been recruited and trained using the Teachers’ Induction Training module recently endorsed by the Ministry of Education for use by all Education in Emergency actors; • The Education Cannot Wait facilitated Multi-Year Resilience Programme in Afghanistan has contributed to reaching 56% of children affected by emergencies in 2019. It should be noted that 20,000 more girls than boys have been enrolled.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

sida:strategy.sida:titleSV: Global strategi för socialt hållbar utveckling 2018-2022

title.narrative: COVID-19 Förbättring av mödra- och nyföddas vård i DRK - SANRU
COVID-19 SANRU - Improving Maternal and Newborn Health Care in DRC

description.narrative:
New/additional funds to address COVID-19 Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 DRC is a country with very poor health indicators as far as maternal and infant/child health is concerned. Sanru has submitted an application for funding for its project on improving maternal and neonatal care in DRC, through accelerating the conversion of nurses to midwives, rehabilitation and equipment of maternity wards and improving overal delivery care in two priority provinces in DRC (Kasai and Maniema). The project includes also a community mobilization aspect to ensure that utilization of services is optimal by all categories of påopulation in need, especially vulnerable women and young people.
Sanru will work in partnership with two nursing schools that will conduct the training, one school in each respective province. The curriculum has been developed by the Ministries of Health and that of Higher Education with technical support from UNFPA. Further improvement of skills for in-service maternity care staff will be performed, to ensure the skills of already trained midwives are up-to-date. One Swedish academic institution with expertise in midwifery will be relied upon to fulfill a quality assurance function, to ensure the academic trainig provided as well as the continued development of the midwives is in line with the internation standards established by WHO as well as the International Midwifery Council (IMC).
The strengthening of human resources for maternity and neonatal care will be accompanied by improvements in physical infrastructure for delivery care, by providing basic maternity equipment as well lighting (using solar energy) in maternities in need. Conditions for better sanitation and hygiene will also be enhanced at a number of maternity wards. Behavioural change in communities will be boosted by a number of activities to fight negative cultural attitudes, raise awareness on available services and to promote utilization of services, including family planning. The project will support the conversion of 240 nurses into midwives and will rehabilitate and provide basic maternity equipment, including lighting system using solar energy and water sytems to 100 maternities (in hospitals and health centers). The project is expected to contribute to an annual increase of utilization of maternal, neonatal, child and adolescent health (MNCAH) services by 3 % and to reduce maternal mortality rate by 7% by 2021.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 DRK är ett land med mycket dåliga hälsoindikatorer vad gäller kvinnors- och barnhälsa. Sanru har lämnat in en ansökan om finansiering för sitt projekt om förbättring av förlossnings- och nyföddas vård i DRK med syftet att påskynda omvandlingen av sjuksköterskor till barnmorskor, rehabilitering och utrustning av förlossningsavdelningar i två prioriterade provinser i landet (Kasai och Maniema). Projektet innehåller också en mobiliseringsaspekt av det lokala samhället för att säkerställa att utnyttjandet av hälsotjänster är optimalt, särskilt bland utsatta kvinnor och ungdomar.
Sanru kommer att samarbeta med två vårdhögskolor som ska svara för utbildningen, en högskola i respektive provins. En speciell läroplan ska användas för att konvertera sjuksköterskor till barnmorskor. Läroplanen har utarbetats av hälsoministeriet tillsammans med högre utbildningsministeriet med teknisk support från UNFPA. Kompetensutveckling för vårdpersonal inom förlossningsvården kommer att genomföras för att säkerställa att kunskapen hos redan utbildade barnmorskor är aktuell. En svensk akademisk institution med expert kunskap om barnmorskeyrket kommer att involveras för att fylla en kvalitetssäkringsfunktion, för att säkerställa att den akademiska utbildning och den kliniska kompetensutveckling som erbjuds barnmorskorna överensstämmer med de internationella normer som fastställts av WHO och Internationella barnmorskerådet (IMC). Förstärkningen av personalens kompetens för mödravården kommer att åtföljas av förbättringar av den fysiska infrastrukturen (utrustning, belysning (med hjälp av solenergi), vatten och hygien i syfte att förbättra förlossningsvården.
Ett antal aktiviteter ska initieras av lokala organisationer för att motarbeta negativa kulturella attityder, öka medvetenheten om tillgängliga tjänster och för att främja utnyttjande av viktiga sexuella och reproduktiva tjänster, inklusive familjeplanering. Projektet ska finansiera konverteringen av 240 sjuksköterskor till barnmoskor och ska rehabilitera 100 vårdinrättningar (förlossningsavdelingar på sjukhus och vårdcentraler) samt förse dem med grundläggande förlossningsmaterial samt belysning (med solenergi) och vattenförsörjning. Projektet förväntas bidra till en årlig ökning av användning av sexuella och reproduktiva tjänster med 3% samt till en minskning av mödradödligheten i provinserna med 7% till 2021.

This intervention aims at improving maternal and newborn services in two provinces (Kasai and Maniema) by increasing the number of qualified midwives, improving the physical environment in selected maternities (equipement, lighting, and WASH) and mobilizing communities for behavioral change and increased utilization of sexual and reproductive health services. This package of activities is expected to contribute to reduced maternal and neonatal mortality in the country.

tag.narrative: 3.2 - By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births.

3.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att inga spädbarn eller barn under fem år dör av orsaker som hade kunnat förebyggas. Alla länder bör sträva efter att minska den neonatala dödligheten till högst tolv dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda och dödligheten bland barn under fem år till högst 25 dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda.

3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.

5.6 - Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.

5.6 - Säkerställa allmän tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och reproduktiva rättigheter i enlighet med överenskommelserna i handlingsprogrammet från den internationella konferensen om befolkning och utveckling, Pekingplattformen samt slutdokumenten från respektive översynskonferenser.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The results have so far been tremendous: - In less than one year of implementation, and thanks to the Swedish advisory team from the Salhgrenska Academy, the training programme for converting nurses to midwives was subjected to scrutiny and to adaptation. It was therefore decided to prolong the programme from 1 year to 1,5 year to align with International standards and regulations from the WHO and International Council of Midwives. The additional 6 months were to focus specifically on clinical skills development. - Two clinical trainings labs have been built ty the project at the nursing schools (ISTM) in Kindu and Tshikapa. (The embassy has been invited to go and inaugurate these!). The equipment made of mannequins and other materials of these centers has been provided by UNFPA - The first batch of midwives is now ready to graduate. About 100 newly trained midwives are to be redeployed in various health centres in the Maniema and Kasai provinces. The recruitment of the second batch is ongoing and the teachings should start soon around early october. - Tens of maternities are being rehabilitated/constructed. The equipment of these maternities is being acquired and deployed to the provinces progressively. The project enjoys full support by authorities, both nationally (Ministries of Health and of Higher Education) and locally. In addition, the project builds on a strong collaboration with provincial branches of the midwifery association which is also in need of strengthening.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: COVID-19 Förbättring av mödra- och nyföddas vård i DRK - SANRU
COVID-19 SANRU - Improving Maternal and Newborn Health Care in DRC

description.narrative:
New/additional funds to address COVID-19 Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 DRC is a country with very poor health indicators as far as maternal and infant/child health is concerned. Sanru has submitted an application for funding for its project on improving maternal and neonatal care in DRC, through accelerating the conversion of nurses to midwives, rehabilitation and equipment of maternity wards and improving overal delivery care in two priority provinces in DRC (Kasai and Maniema). The project includes also a community mobilization aspect to ensure that utilization of services is optimal by all categories of påopulation in need, especially vulnerable women and young people.
Sanru will work in partnership with two nursing schools that will conduct the training, one school in each respective province. The curriculum has been developed by the Ministries of Health and that of Higher Education with technical support from UNFPA. Further improvement of skills for in-service maternity care staff will be performed, to ensure the skills of already trained midwives are up-to-date. One Swedish academic institution with expertise in midwifery will be relied upon to fulfill a quality assurance function, to ensure the academic trainig provided as well as the continued development of the midwives is in line with the internation standards established by WHO as well as the International Midwifery Council (IMC).
The strengthening of human resources for maternity and neonatal care will be accompanied by improvements in physical infrastructure for delivery care, by providing basic maternity equipment as well lighting (using solar energy) in maternities in need. Conditions for better sanitation and hygiene will also be enhanced at a number of maternity wards. Behavioural change in communities will be boosted by a number of activities to fight negative cultural attitudes, raise awareness on available services and to promote utilization of services, including family planning. The project will support the conversion of 240 nurses into midwives and will rehabilitate and provide basic maternity equipment, including lighting system using solar energy and water sytems to 100 maternities (in hospitals and health centers). The project is expected to contribute to an annual increase of utilization of maternal, neonatal, child and adolescent health (MNCAH) services by 3 % and to reduce maternal mortality rate by 7% by 2021.

This package of activities is expected to contribute to reduced maternal and neonatal mortality in the country.
